Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Midson v. Meeting House Lane Medical Practice, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Malpractice. Physician who became patient's attending physician after diagnosis and beginning treatment was not liable for medical malpractice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: FDJ, LLC v. Determan
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: There are six factors to consider when determining whether equity demands a disregard of the corporate entity: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) absence of corporate records; (4) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (5) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporate directors; and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegality.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Individual members of LLC were not jointly and severally liable for LLC's breach of purchase agreement with business owner.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Timilon Corporation v. Empowerment Justice Center Corporation
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, a party may seek to pierce the corporate veil when necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Judgment. Entry of default judgment was proper in seller's action against entities and their operators alleging failure to pay for air purifiers.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, alter ego or piercing the corporate veil has two elements: (1) the corporate entity whose form is to be disregarded is so dominated and controlled by its alleged alter ego that the corporate entity and its alter ego are, in fact, a single economic unit, and (2) the corporate form to be disregarded causes fraud or some similar injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Kwok
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, when considering on a alter ego or veil piercing claim whether corporate form causes fraud or similar injustice or fraudulent intent in the creation of the corporate form – it is only necessary to establish that the corporate form causes fraud or a similar injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Chapter 11 bankruptcy trustee had standing to bring turnover claim on behalf of creditors at large.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Murphy v. Jewell
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While the decision whether to pierce the corporate veil in a given instance will necessarily depend on the attendant facts and equities, piercing the corporate veil generally requires a showing that: (1) the owner exercised complete domination of the corporation or limited liability corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil which resulted in that party's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Plaintiffs stated claim for piercing corporate veil against sole shareholder who allegedly wound down company following accident to be judgment proof.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Louis Monteleone Fibres, Ltd. v. Hudson Baylor Brookhaven, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While decision whether to pierce the corporate veil in a given instance will necessarily depend on the attendant facts and equities, generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation or limited liability company (LLC) in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil which resulted in the party's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Waste-paper broker sufficiently alleged facts to support claim to pierce corporate veil of LLCs to hold its members personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Louis Monteleone Fibres, Ltd. v. Hudson Baylor Brookhaven, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, plaintiff must adequately allege existence of corporate obligation and that defendant exercised complete domination and control over corporation and abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Waste-paper broker sufficiently alleged facts to support claim to pierce corporate veil of LLCs to hold its members personally liable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re DuMouchelle
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, piercing a corporate veil is an equitable remedy that should only be invoked in instances of fraud, illegality, or injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Gem flipper fraudulently induced transfer of funds to his LLC through false pretenses, not larceny, and thus voidable title passed to LLC under Michigan law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Stewart Homes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the second element of the alter ego test, namely, that plaintiff must show an inequitable result will follow if the court rejects the alter ego theory, requires facts sufficient to demonstrate that conduct amounting to bad faith makes it inequitable for the corporate owner to hide behind the corporate form.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING  Attachment and Garnishment. Bank demonstrated probable validity of fraudulent transfer claim under California law, as required to issue writ of attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. v. Stewart Homes, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, there must be direct evidence of specific manipulative conduct for a court to find alter ego; the specific manipulative conduct must include some conduct amounting to bad faith which would make it inequitable for the equitable owner of a corporation to hide behind its corporate veil.
Document Preview: FINANCE AND BANKING  Attachment and Garnishment. Bank demonstrated probable validity of fraudulent transfer claim under California law, as required to issue writ of attachment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dragons 516 Limited v. Knights Genesis Investment Limited
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil to reach the owners of a corporation requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of limited liability company's (LLC) corporate veil to reach parent companies in fraud and conversion action was not warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dragons 516 Limited v. Knights Genesis Investment Limited
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil to reach a corporation's owners must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of limited liability company's (LLC) corporate veil to reach parent companies in fraud and conversion action was not warranted.

Title: Eletson Holdings, Inc. v. Levona Holdings Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: An alter-ego relationship is not easy to establish and exists only where the instrumentality is so extensively controlled that a relationship of principal and agent is created or where affording the entity separate juridical status would work fraud or injustice; common ownership and control is not enough.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Arbitrator exceeded his authority by ordering nonparties, as purported alter egos of party to arbitration, to pay damages to shipping company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Alter ego applies, supporting piercing of corporate veil, when there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased and holding only the corporation liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Injustice prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not met in truck driver's personal injury action against trucking companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: The "injustice" prong of the alter ego basis for piercing the corporate veil requires more than a judge's or juror's subjective perception of unfairness in holding only the corporation liable.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Injustice prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not met in truck driver's personal injury action against trucking companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: The "injustice" prong of the alter ego basis for piercing the corporate veil references the kinds of abuse that the corporate structure should not shield, like fraud, evasion of existing obligations, circumvention of statutes, monopolization, criminal conduct, and the like; such abuse is necessary before disregarding the existence of a corporation as a separate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Injustice prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not met in truck driver's personal injury action against trucking companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: To satisfy the "injustice" prong of the alter ego basis for piercing the corporate veil, a plaintiff must prove that he has fallen victim to a basically unfair device by which a corporate entity has been used to achieve an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Injustice prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not met in truck driver's personal injury action against trucking companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: JNM Express, LLC v. Lozano
Court: Supreme Court of Texas.
Headnote: Standing alone, a corporate employer's choice not to participate in workers' compensation system cannot compel the unrelated finding of "injustice" necessary to satisfy the injustice prong of the alter ego analysis for piercing employer's corporate veil. Tex. Labor Code Ann. § 406.002(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Injustice prong for piercing corporate veil on alter ego theory was not met in truck driver's personal injury action against trucking companies.

Title: Brightstar LLC v. Jordan
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division I.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a fact finder must find three elements by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) the entity is the alter ego of the individual; (2) justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the entity and the individual over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim; and (3) disregarding the corporate form will achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Arbitration. Arbitrator did not exhibit partiality against defendants by rolling his eyes or shaking his head in response to a witness evading questions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ene v. Graham
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: The essence of the alter ego doctrine is to do justice whenever it appears that the protections provided by the corporate form are being abused.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Evidence that LLC's single member occasionally used LLC's property for personal enjoyment did not support alter ego determination.

Title: Ene v. Graham
Court: Supreme Court of Nevada.
Headnote: Under-capitalization, where it is clearly shown, is an important factor in determining whether the doctrine of alter ego should be applied; absent fraud or injustice, however, it is not an absolute ground for disregarding a corporate entity.

Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: Webb v. Medicalodges, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Missouri, Western Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law as to alter ego liability, corporate forms will be ignored and the corporate veil pierced only if three factors are shown: (1) control, which is not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Estate of skilled nursing facility resident put forth sufficient allegations to pierce the corporate veil of corporation which operated facility.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Franks v. Coopersurgical, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Rhode Island.
Headnote: Rhode Island courts are reluctant to pierce the corporate veil and will only do so to prevent injustice.
Document Preview: PRODUCTS LIABILITY  Preemption. Patient's products liability claim on theory of design defect was preempted by Medical Device Amendments of Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Boulder Falcon, LLC v. Brown
Court: United States District Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Utah law, nonexhaustive factors to be considered in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil are: (1) undercapitalization of a one-man corporation; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment of dividends; (4) siphoning of corporate funds by the dominant stockholder; (5) nonfunctioning of other officers or directors; (6) absence of corporate records; (7) the use of the corporation as a facade for operations of the dominant stockholder or stockholders; and (8) the use of the corporate entity in promoting injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Genuine disputes of material fact precluded summary judgment in favor of defendants on LLC's claim for breach of contract under Georgia law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: SonicSolutions Algae Control, LLC v. Diversified Power International, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Tennessee law does not solely limit alter ego analysis to the textbook example of piercing the veil to reach a shareholder; it authorizes the inquiry upon a showing that the entity is a sham or a dummy or where necessary to accomplish justice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Implied Contracts. Genuine issues of material fact existed as to whether implied-in-fact contract existed between distributor and manufacturer under Massachusetts law.

Title: In re Ward
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Georgia, Valdosta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, protection of corporate veil can be set aside if court finds that individual shareholder has used corporate form to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud, promote crime, evade contractual or tort responsibility, or for any other reason which in equity or good conscience would justify disregard of corporate entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Creditors failed to pierce the corporate veil under Georgia law so as to hold Chapter 7 debtor personally liable for his businesses' debts.

Title: In re Ward

Headnote: Under Georgia law, to pierce corporate veil, complaining party must not only show that some injustice occurred, but that shareholder wrongfully used corporate form to perpetuate that harm.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Generally, under New York law, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury; the same requirements apply when seeking to reverse-pierce the corporate veil.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the requirement for piercing the corporate veil that a shareholder used the corporation to commit a fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury can be satisfied either by showing outright fraud, or another type of wrong, such as a breach of a legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; the law requires only that the shareholder's wrongdoing resulted in the plaintiff's injury, not that the injuries suffered by the plaintiff were caused by the shareholder's wrongful conduct to the exclusion of all other possible influences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Guarantor exercised domination over LLCs such that they had become a mere instrumentality of him, as required to reverse-pierce their corporate veils.

Title: Citibank, N.A. v. Aralpa Holdings Limited Partnership
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, relevant inquiry to reverse-pierce the corporate veil is not whether a corporation was formed to commit a fraud or wrong, but whether a corporation was used to commit a fraud or wrong.

Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under New York law, a plaintiff must show that (1) the controlling entity exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction at issue, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong that injured the party seeking to pierce the veil.

Title: Doheny v. International Business Machines, Corp.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Instead of a firm rule, the general principle guiding courts in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil under the federal common law is that liability is imposed when doing so would achieve an equitable result.

Title: Moon v. Owadeyah

Headnote: While complete domination of corporation is key to piercing corporate veil, especially when owners use corporation as mere device to further their personal rather than corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.

Title: Palmtag v. Republican Party of Nebraska

Headnote: A court will disregard a corporation's identity only where the corporation has been used to commit fraud, violate a legal duty, or perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the rights of another.

Headnote: Under Kentucky law, two elements must be met in order to pierce corporate veil: (1) domination of corporation resulting in loss of corporate separateness and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Coast-to-Coast Produce, LLC v. Lakeside Produce USA, Inc.

Title: In re Dravo LLC
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate form whenever it is necessary to avoid injustice, and so long as the rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced or the theory of corporate entity rendered useless.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, piercing corporate veil is inappropriate unless some fraud or injustice would be perpetrated through misuse of corporate form.

Title: In re Jung
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, courts will look through corporate organizations and to individuals when necessary to prevent injustice, but doing so is the exception rather than the rule, and, ordinarily, a corporation will be regarded as a separate legal entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor did not make false representation with reckless disregard for the truth, within meaning of dischargeability exception.

Title: Lifetouch National School Studios Inc. v. Oklahoma School Pictures, LLC
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 4.
Headnote: For purposes of the theory of alter ego liability, doctrine that corporation is a legal entity, separate and apart from persons composing it, is legal theory introduced for purposes of convenience and to subserve ends of justice, but concept will not be extended to point beyond its reason and policy, and when invoked in support of end subversive of said policy will be disregarded by courts.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Triable issues of fact existed as to whether LLC created judgment debtor as an instrumentality to wrongfully obtain clients and business.

Title: Groth v. Ferrante
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Concept of piercing corporate veil is exception to general rule that corporation exists independently of its owners, who are not personally liable for its obligations, and who may incorporate for express purpose of limiting their liability, which exception courts will invoke only where necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor to reach shareholders was not warranted in judgment creditors' action seeking to enforce default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Groth v. Ferrante
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation with respect to challenged transaction, and (2) that domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff which resulted in injury to plaintiff; in addition to complete domination of corporation, pleading must allege abuse of privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil of judgment debtor to reach shareholders was not warranted in judgment creditors' action seeking to enforce default judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Paul v. Bathurst
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: There are six factors to consider when determining whether equity demands a disregard of the corporate entity: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) absence of corporate records; (4) payment by the corporation of individual obligations; (5) fraudulent misrepresentation by corporate directors; and (6) use of the corporation to promote fraud, injustice or illegality.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Independent Contractors. Whether ranch manager was an employee or independent contractor, for statute of limitation purposes, could not be resolved on motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Paul v. Bathurst
Court: Supreme Court of South Dakota.
Headnote: The six factors to consider when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil can be grouped into two separate prongs: the "separate corporate identity" prong and the "fraud or inequitable consequences" prong; if the four factors under the "separate corporate identity" prong are present in sufficient number and/or degree, then the court will consider the two factors under the "fraud or inequitable consequences" prong.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Independent Contractors. Whether ranch manager was an employee or independent contractor, for statute of limitation purposes, could not be resolved on motion to dismiss.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Archival, Inc. v. 177 Realty Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: To survive motion to dismiss complaint, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must allege facts that, if proved, establish that party against whom doctrine is asserted: (1) exercised complete domination over corporation with respect to transaction at issue, and (2) through such domination, abused privilege of doing business in corporate form to perpetrate wrong or injustice against plaintiff such that court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Property purchaser, which sought to pierce corporate veil, adequately pleaded seller's members, owners, and/or shareholders dominated purchaser.

Title: Doherty v. Town of Woodstock

Headnote: The court will look beyond the corporation to its shareholders for liability, that is, pierce the corporate veil, where the corporate form has been used to perpetrate a fraud, and also where the needs of justice dictate. 11A Vt. Stat. Ann. § 6.22(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose liability on corporation's sole shareholder was unwarranted in action arising from slip and fall on sidewalk.

Title: Doherty v. Town of Woodstock

Headnote: In cases not involving fraudulent activity, the court will look to the facts and circumstances of each case to determine whether the corporate veil should be pierced in the interests of fairness, equity, and the public need. 11A Vt. Stat. Ann. § 6.22(b).

Title: Hasty v. Greyhawk Development Corporation

Title: Liberty Aviation Museum, Inc. v. JRM Marine Consulting, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth District, Ottawa County.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show that (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing contractor's corporate veil to reach the assets of owner's father who took control after owner suffered a stroke was not warranted.

Title: Johnson v. Cricket Council USA, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Western Division.
Headnote: In order to prevail on a request to pierce the corporate veil under North Carolina's instrumentality rule, the aggrieved party must establish three elements: (1) stockholders' control of the corporation amounts to complete domination with respect to the transaction at issue, (2) stockholders' use of this control to commit a wrong, and (3) this wrong or breach of duty must be the proximate cause of the injury.

Title: In re Howard

Headnote: Under Florida law, piercing the corporate veil is an exception to the general principle of corporate law that shareholders of a corporation are protected against personal liability for corporate obligations unless it be shown that the corporation is formed or used for some illegal, fraudulent, or other unjust purpose which justifies piercing the corporate veil.

Title: Presidio, Inc. v. People Driven Technology, Inc.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must show: (1) that the business entity and its owner operated as a single economic entity, and (2) that there was an overall element of injustice or unfairness.

Title: Presidio, Inc. v. People Driven Technology, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Because the trappings of sophisticated corporate life are rarely present in privately-held corporations, courts must avoid an over-rigid preoccupation with questions of structure when the corporate veil of a private company can be pierced; rather, courts should focus on applying the overarching principle that liability is imposed to reach an equitable result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Affiliate of purchaser of family business lacked valid and enforceable contract with affiliate's former employees based on assigned agreements.

Title: Gold v. 22 St. Felix, LLC

Headnote: While decision whether to pierce corporate veil in given instance will necessarily depend on attendant facts and equities, generally piercing corporate veil requires showing that: (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation or limited liability company (LLC) in respect to transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against party seeking to pierce corporate veil which resulted in party's injury.

Title: 138-77 Queens Blvd LLC v. Silver

Title: Riverview Carpet & Flooring, Inc. v. Presbyterian SeniorCare
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A corporate veil will be pierced and the corporate form disregarded whenever justice or public policy demand, such as when the corporate form has been used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.

Title: In re Nilhan Financial, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, M.D. Florida, Tampa Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, to successfully pierce the corporate veil, claimant must prove that: (1) corporation is mere instrumentality of shareholder, i.e., shareholder dominated and controlled the corporation to such an extent that it did not have an independent existence and shareholder was in fact an alter ego of the corporation; (2) shareholder engaged in improper conduct, i.e., the corporate form was used fraudulently or for an improper purpose; and (3) the fraudulent or improper use of the corporate form caused injury to claimant.

Title: Hacker v. Fabe
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: Two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked; first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.

Title: Franklin Capital Funding, LLC v. Austin Business Finance, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil of a corporate entity, when considering whether a fraud or wrong was effected, it is not necessary to prove that the owner caused the entity to directly harm the complainant; it is sufficient that the owner exercised his or her control over the entity in such a manner as to wrong the complainant.

Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Although complete domination of the corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil under New York law, especially when the owners use the corporation as a mere device to further their personal rather than the corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward the plaintiff is required.

Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, corporate veils exist for a reason and should be pierced only reluctantly and cautiously; because the law permits the incorporation of businesses for the very purpose of isolating liabilities among separate entities, the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, when the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or to promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show both control of the company by wrongdoers and an impropriety that constitutes a misuse of the company by them as a device or facade to conceal their wrongdoing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Deutsche Bank AG v. Sebastian Holdings, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: In Connecticut, New York, and the Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI), piercing the corporate veil is an extraordinary remedy that requires, at a minimum, a determination by the court that the corporate form was used to promote a wrong or injustice, and that a fundamental unfairness would result from a failure to disregard the corporate form; in none of these jurisdictions is it sufficient only to show that the defendant exercised complete domination and control over the corporation or commingled assets, as the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must also show that the corporate form was a mere shell used primarily as an intermediary to perpetrate fraud or to promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Equitable factors rendered harmless any error in application of Turks and Caicos law to bank's claim for piercing judgment debtor's corporate veil.

Title: Rosenshein v. Kushner
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.

Title: Arnold v. LME, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: A corporation's inability to pay its debt alone is not sufficient to support a finding of injustice under the second prong of the two-prong test for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil from Minn. Laborers Health & Welfare Fund v. Scanlan, 360 F.3d 925, under which the court considers if adherence to the corporate fiction would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to an evasion of legal obligations; rather, it is only when the shareholders disregard the separateness of the corporate identity and when that act of disregard causes the injustice or inequity or constitutes the fraud that the corporate veil may be pierced.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Nature and control of owner-operated corporation weighed against piercing the corporate veil, in former employees' action against corporate owners.

Title: UMB Bank, N.A. v. Eagle Crest Apartments, LLC

Title: BMO Harris Bank N.A. v. Kuskie

Title: Pierre Investments, Inc. v. CLS Capital Group, Inc.

Headnote: Evidence of individuals' domination of a corporation, alone, does not suffice to pierce the corporate veil without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Trial court acted within its discretion in denying motion to amend complaint against corporation to add corporation's principals as defendants.

Title: In re Contempt of Pavlos-Hackney
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the separate existence of corporate entities when it is used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Contempt. Contempt orders against business that operated restaurant and its owner after court orders to cease operation of restaurant were civil in nature.

Title: Wolf Designs LLC v. Five 18 Designs LLC

Headnote: To establish alter ego theory of liability, plaintiff must allege: there is unity of control and interest between owner and business entity such that one is alter ego of other, and observing corporate form's privileges and protections would be unjust.

Title: Board of Trustees, Sheet Metal Workers' National Pension Fund v. Allure Metal Works, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.

Title: Liberty Highrise Pvt. Ltd. v. Praxis Energy Agents DMCC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Although there is no firm rule in determining whether two entities are alter egos, the general principle guiding courts in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil has been that liability is imposed when doing so would achieve an equitable result.

Title: In re Wolf
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Although, under Illinois law, a corporation is a legal entity separate and distinct from its shareholders, directors, and officers, this separate and distinct legal entity will be disregarded, and the corporate veil pierced, where observance of the fiction of separate identities would sanction a fraud or promote injustice under the circumstances.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Court properly granted Chapter 7 trustee's claim for outside reverse veil-piercing, so as to use corporate assets to satisfy debtor's personal debts.

Title: In re Wolf
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Illinois does not doggedly adhere to the corporate form whenever doing so would sanction an injustice perpetuated by a third party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Court properly granted Chapter 7 trustee's claim for outside reverse veil-piercing, so as to use corporate assets to satisfy debtor's personal debts.

Title: Liu Jo S.P.A. v. Jenner

Headnote: Under California law, piercing corporate veil is warranted when (1) there is unity of interest and ownership such that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist and (2) inequitable result will follow if acts are treated as those of corporation alone.

Title: Pike Cnty. Fiscal Ct. v. RCC Big Shoal, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Kentucky, Southern Division., Pikeville.
Headnote: Circumstances besides fraud that may merit piercing the corporate veil under Kentucky law include: where a party would be unjustly enriched; where a parent corporation that caused a subsidiary's liabilities and its inability to pay for them would escape those liabilities; or an intentional scheme to squirrel assets into a liability-free corporation while heaping liabilities upon an asset-free corporation.

Title: Cam-Carson, LLC v. Carson Reclamation Authority
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: In California, two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked: first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist; second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS  Performance and Breach. Land developer alleged that city and city reclamation authority were alter egos for purposes of developer's claim for breach of contract.

Title: Cam-Carson, LLC v. Carson Reclamation Authority
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: The alter ego doctrine does not require proof of fraud, and can be satisfied by evidence that adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would promote injustice.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT CONTRACTS  Performance and Breach. Land developer alleged that city and city reclamation authority were alter egos for purposes of developer's claim for breach of contract.

Title: Edmondson v. Velvet Lifestyles, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Those who utilize the laws of Florida in order to do business in the corporate form have every right to rely on the rules of law which protect them against liability unless it be shown that the corporation is formed or used for some illegal, fraudulent or other unjust purpose which justifies piercing of the corporate veil.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Misappropriation of Name or Likeness. Manager was not liable for Lanham Act violations absent evidence she knew about, was actively involved in, ratified, or was a moving force.

Title: Edmondson v. Velvet Lifestyles, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit.
Headnote: Courts are reluctant to pierce the corporate veil and will do so only in a court of competent jurisdiction, after notice to and full opportunity to be heard by all parties, and upon showing of cause which necessitates the corporate entity being disregarded in order to prevent some injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Misappropriation of Name or Likeness. Manager was not liable for Lanham Act violations absent evidence she knew about, was actively involved in, ratified, or was a moving force.

Title: In re Maxus Energy Corporation
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil under the alter ego theory requires that the corporate structure cause fraud or similar injustice; effectively, the corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Parent corporation ultimately could be held liable for alleged asset stripping strategy upon which liquidating trust based its alter ego claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Maxus Energy Corporation
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In order to establish "fraud and injustice," which allows for piercing the corporate veil, there must be an abuse of the corporate form, e.g., some sort of elaborate shell game; effectively, the corporate must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Parent corporation ultimately could be held liable for alleged asset stripping strategy upon which liquidating trust based its alter ego claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Maxus Energy Corporation
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: The requisite injustice or unfairness that allows for the corporate veil to be pierced is not simple in nature but rather something that is similar in nature to fraud or a sham.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Parent corporation ultimately could be held liable for alleged asset stripping strategy upon which liquidating trust based its alter ego claim.

Title: In re Maxus Energy Corporation
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: The plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil need not prove that the corporation was created with fraud or unfairness in mind; it is sufficient to prove that it was so used.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Parent corporation ultimately could be held liable for alleged asset stripping strategy upon which liquidating trust based its alter ego claim.

Title: Partner Reinsurance Company Ltd. v. RPM Mortgage, Inc.

Headnote: Under Delaware law, a plaintiff seeking to impose alter ego liability on the owners of a corporate entity must show: (1) the entity in question operated as a single economic entity with its owners; and (2) an overall element of injustice or unfairness.

Title: Partner Reinsurance Company Ltd. v. RPM Mortgage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and hold owners liable for corporate wrongdoing under Delaware law, a plaintiff must show an overall element of injustice or unfairness; to show this, a plaintiff need not prove that there was actual fraud, nor must it prove the corporation was created with fraud or unfairness in mind.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Mortgage bank knowingly refused to close on merger agreement with title insurance company, as required for breach of parties' agreement.

Title: Partner Reinsurance Company Ltd. v. RPM Mortgage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and hold owners liable for corporate wrongdoing under Delaware law, the fraud or injustice to which a plaintiff points must be more than the underlying claim for which it seeks to hold the corporate owner liable.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Mortgage bank knowingly refused to close on merger agreement with title insurance company, as required for breach of parties' agreement.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Partner Reinsurance Company Ltd. v. RPM Mortgage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and hold owners liable for corporate wrongdoing under Delaware law, the corporate structure itself must have been used to further the fraud or injustice or as a shield for unjust acts; in other words, courts look behind the corporate curtain generally where the facts indicate the corporate entity has been or is being used by those in control of it to perpetrate a fraud or to promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Mortgage bank knowingly refused to close on merger agreement with title insurance company, as required for breach of parties' agreement.

Title: In re Flint Water Cases

Headnote: Under Michigan law, a complainant need not prove that the owner of an entity used the entity to commit a specific fraud or wrong, in order to impose alter ego liability by piercing the corporate veil; rather, the question is whether the owner exercised its control over the entity in a manner amounting to a fraud or wrong under such circumstances that a court would aid in the consummation of a wrong if it were to honor the separate existence of the entity.

Title: Cunningham Energy, LLC v. Vesta O&G Holdings, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia, Charleston Division.
Headnote: Under West Virginia law, plaintiffs may pierce the corporate veil to hold shareholders personally liable if: (1) there is a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and of the individual shareholders no longer exist, a disregard of formalities requirement; and (2) an inequitable result would occur if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, a fairness requirement.

Title: Martin v. Top Quality Professional Construction, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: To determine whether party seeking to pierce corporate veil has met its burden, courts consider whether party has presented evidence demonstrating: (1) under capitalization; (2) absence of corporate records; (3) fraudulent representation by corporation shareholders or directors; (4) use of corporation to promote fraud, injustice, or illegal activities; (5) payment by corporation of individual obligations; (6) commingling of assets and affairs; (7) failure to observe required corporate formalities; or (8) other shareholder acts or conduct ignoring, controlling, or manipulating corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Homeowner failed to meet burden to pierce corporate veil in breach of contract claim against limited liability company (LLC).

Title: In re Moldovan
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate veil may be pierced and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misconduct when (1) control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against person seeking to disregard corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.

Title: Ledford v. Keen

Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: The thrust of the "enterprise liability doctrine" is that, just as a corporation's owner or owners may be held liable for judgments against the corporation when equity requires, so may affiliated or "sister" corporations-corporations with common ownership, engaged in a unitary commercial endeavor-be held liable for each other's debts or judgments.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Title: Mortimer v. McCool
Court: Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Corporate veil will be pierced and the corporate form disregarded whenever justice or public policy demand, such as when the corporate form has been used to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Enterprise liability doctrine did not apply to permit judgment creditor to pierce veil of judgment debtor LLC's affiliated corporate entity.

Title: Hunter v. Shield
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: The test in Ohio for whether a court can pierce the corporate veil is whether: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Sales. Contract for sale and installation of a ceramic home coating product was predominately a contract for sale of goods under the UCC.

Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Pursuant to the identity rule for piercing the corporate veil, if the plaintiff can show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.

Title: DeJesus v. R.P.M. Enterprises, Inc.

Title: Cork v. CC-Palo Alto, Inc.

Headnote: To invoke California's alter-ego doctrine, under which the courts will ignore the corporate entity and deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons or organizations actually controlling the corporation, a plaintiff must allege: (1) that there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two corporations no longer exist; and (2) that if the acts are treated as those of only one of the corporations, an inequitable result will follow.

Title: Alvarez Galvez v. Fanjul Corporation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: The federal common law alter ego rule requires that three elements be proved in order to pierce the corporate veil: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practices in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.

Title: Qun Lin v. Cruz

Headnote: In Maryland, courts will allow a plaintiff to pierce the corporate veil and disregard the corporate fiction only in instances of fraud or when necessary to enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Remand was warranted for court to determine whether purported owner was owner of restaurant either by piercing corporate veil or economic reality test under FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Qun Lin v. Cruz
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Because piercing the corporate veil is founded on equity, where no fraud is shown, the plaintiff must show that an inequitable result, involving fundamental unfairness, will result from a failure to disregard the corporate form.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Remand was warranted for court to determine whether purported owner was owner of restaurant either by piercing corporate veil or economic reality test under FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, alter ego claim requires a showing of: (1) total domination and control of one entity by another, and (2) inequitable consequences caused thereby.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Second prong of two-pronged test applied by South Carolina courts in deciding whether to pierce corporate veil considers whether the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil would suffer injustice or fundamental unfairness if the acts of the corporation are not regarded as the acts of individual shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re AuditHead, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Burden of proving fundamental unfairness as prerequisite under South Carolina law for piercing the corporate veil requires plaintiff to establish that: (1) defendant was aware of plaintiff's claim against the corporation, and (2) thereafter the defendant acted in self-serving manner with regard to the property of the corporation and in disregard of the plaintiff's claim in the property.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Case Administration. Substantive consolidation could not be applied in order to bring assets of alleged non-debtor successor into debtor-LLC's estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Butler America, LLC v. Aviation Assurance Company, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: Ordinarily a corporation, or in this case a limited liability entity, is regarded as a separate legal entity, but where such an entity is used to perpetrate fraud or to accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, a court may disregard the entity and treat its acts as if done by the persons actually controlling it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Substantial evidence established that debtor's owner and related entities were its alter egos, warranting amendment of judgment to add them as debtors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Butler America, LLC v. Aviation Assurance Company, LLC
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 6, California.
Headnote: In addition to showing a unity of ownership, the party seeking to impose alter ego liability must show an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the entity alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Judgment. Substantial evidence established that debtor's owner and related entities were its alter egos, warranting amendment of judgment to add them as debtors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re All Terrain, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: In order to establish an alter ego claim, plaintiff must prove (1) a unity of interest and ownership to a degree that the separate personalities of the individual and the corporation no longer exist, and (2) that an inequitable result would follow if the acts are treated as acts of corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Proof of claim could not be allowed on single business enterprise theory of veil-piercing.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Royal Alice Properties, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, traditional veil-piercing doctrines are generally limited to cases in which the separate existence of corporation has been abused, and in which court finds that piercing the corporate veil is necessary to remedy fraud, illegality, or other inequitable conduct by corporation's shareholders.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Common ownership and commingling of funds supported single business enterprise claim against debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: United States v. Dynamic Visions Inc
Court: United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit.
Headnote: A court may hold the owner of a corporation responsible for the corporation's conduct when there is a unity of interest between the individual and the entity, and when insulating the owner from liability would lead to inequitable results.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Medical Assistance. Home health care provider knowingly submitted false Medicaid reimbursement claims and also did so with reckless disregard for their falsity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Moss v. Associated Underwriters, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Nebraska.
Headnote: A court will disregard a corporation's identity only where the corporation has been used to commit fraud, violate a legal duty, or perpetrate a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the rights of another.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence warranted piercing corporate veil of insurance corporation to hold corporation's sole shareholder liable for unpaid judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Edmonson v. State
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: An exception to the general rule that a corporation's legal existence is separate and apart from its officers is that the distinct corporate identity will not to be maintained if to do so would subvert the ends of justice.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE  Indictment and Information. Indictment sufficiently charged defendant individually for check fraud despite inclusion of name of his company that had checking account in issue.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Arben Corporation v. Durastone, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LITIGATION  Judgment. Judgment creditor could not enforce judgment against alleged alter egos of judgment debtor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Roley v. National Professional Exchange, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, a corporate entity will be disregarded only when necessary to prevent fraud or to enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Former employee's travel expense reimbursements constituted wages under Maryland Wage Payment and Collection Law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Donis v. American Waste Services, LLC
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Norfolk.
Headnote: The "corporate disregard doctrine" is an equitable tool that authorizes courts, in rare situations, to ignore corporate formalities, where such disregard is necessary to provide a meaningful remedy for injuries and to avoid injustice or to carry out legislative intent and to avoid evasion of statutes.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Employees could not recover under Wage Act for alleged underpayment in violation of Prevailing Wage Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hartshorne v. Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany
Court: Supreme Court, New York, Schenectady County.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Benefit Plans. Pension plan participants adequately alleged facts that, if true, would permit diocese to be held liable as employer's alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Cambridge Valley Machining, Inc. v. Hudson MFG LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. New York.
Headnote: Texas law permits piercing the corporate veil to prevent fraud or to achieve equity. Tex. Bus. Org. Code § 21.223(b).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: United States v. Kindred Healthcare, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A case must present an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness in order for the court to pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator sufficiently alleged that nursing home operators knew staffing levels they mandated made it impossible to provide for their residents' needs.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ingham v. Johnson & Johnson
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION TWO.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must prove three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: TORTS  Negligence. Specific personal jurisdiction existed over manufacturer of cosmetic products as to 15 non-resident consumers' complaints regarding shower product.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: International Union, United Mine Workers of America v. CONSOL Energy, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. West Virginia, at Bluefield.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil should only be done in extreme cases where the interests of justice require it, such as in matters of fraud or where other significant equitable considerations are present.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Meadowfresh Solutions USA, LLC v. Maple Grove Farms, LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division One.
Headnote: When a corporation or an limited liability company (LLC) is used for an improper purpose and to perpetuate injustice by which it avoids its legal obligations, equity will step in, pierce the corporate veil and grant appropriate relief.

Title: Meadowfresh Solutions USA, LLC v. Maple Grove Farms, LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division One.
Headnote: The requisite proof for establishing a claim for piercing the corporate veil requires: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Issue of whether company was alter ego was actually litigated and decided in prior jury trial, as necessary for estoppel to preclude relitigation.

Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that the financial setup of the corporation is a sham and causes an injustice.

Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
