Title: In re L. Scott Apparel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, an alter ego relationship requires (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and its owner no longer exist, and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Bankruptcy Court's recharacterization of $350,000 loan from claimant to debtor as equity and not debt under Delaware law was not clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re L. Scott Apparel, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: To establish an alter ego relationship under California law, a plaintiff must show that an injustice would result from the recognition of separate corporate identities, and difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy this standard.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Bankruptcy Court's recharacterization of $350,000 loan from claimant to debtor as equity and not debt under Delaware law was not clearly erroneous.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Holly v. Alta Newport Hospital, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, to establish an alter ego relationship between a corporation and its equitable owner, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: HEALTH  Medical Records. Alleged negligence that led to public disclosure of hospital patient's private health information did not occur in rendering of professional services.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Grayiel v. AIO Holdings, LLC
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Kentucky, Louisville Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, to pierce a corporate veil, a court must find: (1) domination of the corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Summary judgment was precluded on investor's actual fraudulent conveyance claim against entity allegedly involved in natural gas drilling scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Gral
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Wisconsin.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, veil-piercing doctrine applies to overcome strong presumption that corporations and like entities are legally distinct from their owners when: (1) an individual owner uses his complete domination of an entity to commit a fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or to commit a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of another's legal rights, and (2) that misconduct proximately causes injury or loss.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Avoidance. Trustee's threadbare allegations did not state plausible fraudulent transfer avoidance claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Miami Products & Chemical Co. v. Olin Corporation
Court: United States District Court, W.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Conspiracy. Buyers of caustic soda sufficiently alleged sellers engaged in parallel conduct, stating claim under Sherman Act's restraint of trade provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Hess
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. New Mexico.
Headnote: Under New Mexico law, it is only under special circumstances that courts will disregard the corporate entity in order to pierce corporate veil and hold individual shareholders personally liable, as when corporation was set up for fraudulent purposes, or when recognizing corporation would result in injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Jaques
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: "Inequitable result" requirement for piercing the corporate veil under Idaho law is satisfied by something less than an affirmative showing of fraud, but requires something more than the mere prospect of an unsatisfied judgment.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debtor's misuse of trust funds supported fiduciary fraud or defalcation claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Doe v. Bausch & Lomb, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, a court will disregard the corporate structure and pierce the corporate veil only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Corporate veil may also be pierced under Tennessee law upon a showing that the corporation is a sham or a dummy or where necessary to accomplish justice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issue existed whether licensees suffered damages from licensor's alleged breach of contract for failure to provide notice and cure period, precluding summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Best Choice Roofing & Home Improvement, Inc. v. Best Choice Roofing Savannah, LLC
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under Tennessee law must show that complete dominion and control over a corporation was used to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetuate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of third parties' rights.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Fact issue existed whether licensees suffered damages from licensor's alleged breach of contract for failure to provide notice and cure period, precluding summary judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Zhang v. Chu
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: Courts may disregard the corporate entity when the corporation is merely the alter ego of its stockholders: called "piercing the corporate veil," this equitable doctrine gives creditors access to the stockholders' personal assets when the corporation's assets are so minimal that their small size would defeat a plaintiff's judgment against the corporation, thus creating an inequitable result.
Document Preview: TORTS  Malicious Prosecution. Company owner failed to establish that attorney added him as defendant in underlying wage-and-hour action maliciously.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Alexander v. Community Hospital of Long Beach
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 1, California.
Headnote: Two requirements must be met to invoke the alter ego doctrine to disregard corporate identity: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist'; and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Wrongful Discharge. Substantial evidence did not support hospital's liability to nurses for negligent supervision of director alleged to have created hostile work environment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Constellation-F, LLC v. World Trading 23, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 8, California.
Headnote: A plaintiff seeking to invoke the alter ego doctrine must prove two conditions: (1) unity of interest and ownership between the two entities and (2) an inequitable result if the two entities are not equally liable.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Landlord and Tenant. Holdover rent provision increasing base rent by 150% if tenant remained after lease expired was not an unenforceable penalty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Clark Rigging & Rental Corp. v. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Plaintiff sufficiently alleged that limited liability company's alleged alter ego was in fact its alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Clark Rigging & Rental Corp. v. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: Wrongdoing necessary to pierce the corporate veil on an alter-ego theory does not necessarily require allegations of actual fraud; while fraud certainly satisfies the wrongdoing requirement, other claims of inequity or malfeasance will also suffice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Plaintiff sufficiently alleged that limited liability company's alleged alter ego was in fact its alter ego.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ferrante v. Westin St. John Hotel Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: When deciding to pierce the corporate veil, North Carolina courts consider (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only in finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Condominiums. Condominium developer's refusal to allow time share owners to use time share was not a breach of contract under the law of the U.S. Virgin Islands.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ferrante v. Westin St. John Hotel Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. North Carolina, Eastern Division.
Headnote: North Carolina courts focus on the reality of the situation and determine if an element of injustice or abuse of corporate privilege exists when evaluating the elements for deciding whether to pierce the corporate veil, which include control, breach of duty, and proximate cause.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Missouri Ozarks Radio, Network, Inc. v. Baugh
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Southern District, Division Two.
Headnote: For a court to disregard the business entity or pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must demonstrate that the entity had: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: E-COMMERCE  Internet. Internet domain name administrator's selling of domain name after unauthorized transfer of ownership gave rise to independent tort of conversion.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Bullitt Utilities, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Kentucky.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, decision to pierce corporate veil depends on two dispositive elements: (1) domination of corporation resulting in a loss of corporate separateness, and (2) circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Trustee could not pursue breach-of-fiduciary-duty claims against former officer/director.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: General Fidelity Insurance Company v. WFT, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: While a corporation's separate and independent existence from its shareholders is not to be disregarded lightly, courts should disregard the corporate form when it would accomplish some fraudulent purpose, operate as a constructive fraud, or defeat some strong equitable claim.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Insurance company was winding up when it transferred assets to second company, as necessary for transfer of assets to constitute constructive fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Webber v. Deck
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Under New Hampshire law, the alter ego doctrine applies and individual liability for a corporate owner is assessed where the owners have used the corporate identity to promote an injustice or fraud on the plaintiffs.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Employer's Liability. Event attendee failed to allege event organizer was vicariously liable for torts allegedly committed by officers who removed attendee from event.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Transparent GMU v. George Mason University
Court: Supreme Court of Virginia.
Headnote: Piercing a corporate veil is an extraordinary act to be taken only when necessary to promote justice.
Document Preview: EDUCATION  Records. Privately held nonprofit corporation established to raise funds for the benefit of university was not subject to Virginia Freedom of Information Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Nungesser Industries LLC v. City of Jackson
Court: Court of Appeals of Mississippi.
Headnote: A company's distinct corporate identity will be maintained unless to do so would subvert the ends of justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parties. Mississippi LLC lacked standing to bring breach of contract action against city for failure to pay for tornado damage cleanup performed by Louisiana LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mou v. SSC San Jose Operating Company LP
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: Under the California "alter ego doctrine," when the corporate form is used to perpetrate a fraud, circumvent a statute, or accomplish some other wrongful or inequitable purpose, the courts will ignore the corporate entity and deem the corporation's acts to be those of the persons or organizations actually controlling the corporation, in most instances the equitable owners.
Document Preview: ANTITRUST  Pleading. Former nursing home resident failed to state claim for violation of California's UCL, predicated on alleged violations of various California and federal statutes and regulations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: California Expanded Metal Products Company v. Klein
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Under Washington law, piercing the corporate veil requires proof of two elements: (1) the corporate form must be intentionally used to violate or evade a duty, and (2) disregard of the corporate form must be necessary and required to prevent unjustified loss to the injured party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Washington law, competitor could not be held personally liable for his corporation's alleged direct infringement of patents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: California Expanded Metal Products Company v. Klein
Court: United States District Court, W.D. Washington, at Seattle.
Headnote: Under Washington law, to satisfy the disregard of corporate form element required to pierce the corporate veil, the party seeking relief must show that disregarding the corporate veil is necessary and required to prevent an unjustified loss to the injured party.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under Washington law, competitor could not be held personally liable for his corporation's alleged direct infringement of patents.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sereda v. Center City Acquisitions, LLC
Court: Superior Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: A court may pierce the corporate veil to find an individual in the corporation personally liable for actions of the corporation when equity requires it to prevent fraud, illegality or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported trial court's piercing of corporate veil to find LLC's president personally liable for shoddy construction of a home sold by LLC.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: TMCC, Inc. v. Jennifer Convertibles, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Landlord failed to allege that tenant's parent company used domination of tenant to breach commercial lease, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: TMCC, Inc. v. Jennifer Convertibles, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Evidence of domination of a corporation alone does not suffice for purposes of piercing the corporate veil without an additional showing that it led to inequity, fraud, or malfeasance.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parent and Subsidiary. Landlord failed to allege that tenant's parent company used domination of tenant to breach commercial lease, as required to pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Northgate Ventures LLC v. Geoffrey H. Garrett PLLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 1.
Headnote: Two separate, essential factors must be established for a court to pierce the corporate veil: first, the corporate form must be used to violate or evade a duty and second, the fact finder must establish that disregarding the corporate veil is necessary and required to prevent an unjustified loss to the injured party.
Document Preview: LEGAL SERVICES  Law Firms. Dissolving law firm was not required to assign its clients, client list, and client files to receiver.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: AKH Company, Inc. v. Universal Underwriters Insurance Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine applies where (1) there is unity of interest and ownership such that separate personalities of the corporation and the alter egos do not exist, and (2) there would be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Duty to Defend. Cost-sharing agreement for defense costs in consolidated suits against and by insured did not breach duty to defend.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: AKH Company, Inc. v. Universal Underwriters Insurance Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Kansas.
Headnote: Under California law, inequitable result prong of alter ego test requires direct evidence of specific manipulative conduct that must include some conduct amounting to bad faith which would make it inequitable for the equitable owner of a corporation to hide behind its corporate veil.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Duty to Defend. Cost-sharing agreement for defense costs in consolidated suits against and by insured did not breach duty to defend.

Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: New York courts will disregard corporate form whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.

Title: United States v. Lax
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiff seeking to pierce corporate veil must show that (1) owners exercised complete domination of corporation in respect to transaction attacked; and (2) such domination was used to commit fraud or wrong against plaintiff that resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Title: Durham v. Accardi
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate fiction when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Durham v. Accardi
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: Alter ego veil piercing is appropriate (1) where a corporation is organized and operated as a mere tool or business conduit of another, (2) there is such unity between corporation and individual that the separateness of the corporation has ceased, and (3) holding only the corporation or individual liable would result in injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Durham v. Accardi
Court: Court of Appeals of Texas, Houston (14th Dist.).
Headnote: A corporation's financial strength or weakness must be viewed with consideration of the underlying policy that piercing the corporate veil is necessary to prevent a plaintiff from falling victim to a basically unfair device.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence was insufficient that corporation's representatives were corporation's alter ego and thus employee could not pierce corporate veil.

Title: In re Platinum-Beechwood Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in the plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Receiver for hedge funds failed to state New-York-law aiding and abetting fraud claim against insurer allegedly involved in Ponzi scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Platinum-Beechwood Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, while complete domination of the corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil, especially when the owners use the corporation as a mere device to further their personal rather than the corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward the plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. Receiver for hedge funds failed to state New-York-law aiding and abetting fraud claim against insurer allegedly involved in Ponzi scheme.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sweeney v. Waitz
Court: Supreme Court, Suffolk County, New York.
Headnote: Some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward the plaintiff is required to support the equitable relief of piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY  Contractors and Developers. Allegations that contractor improperly installed air handler and removed load-bearing support beam sounded in breach of contract, not negligence.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Binsara, LLC v. Bolog
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fifth District, Stark County.
Headnote: The focus of the test to decide whether to pierce the corporate veil is the extent to which the shareholder controlled the corporation and whether the shareholder misused his or her control to commit specific egregious acts that injured the plaintiff: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Corporate officers engaged in fraud by entering into contract when corporation was not legal entity, and thus corporate veil could be pierced.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Doe v. Bloomberg, L.P.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: A plaintiff who attempts to pierce the corporate veil and hold a corporate officer or owner liable for an obligation of, or a wrong committed by, the corporation must show complete domination of the corporation and that the individual, through his domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against the plaintiff.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Discrimination. CEO was not individually liable under NYCHRL for sex discrimination absent allegation CEO encouraged, condoned, or approved alleged discrimination.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Cerner Middle East Limited v. iCapital, LLC
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Ninth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Missouri law, the corporate veil may be pierced and a court may conclude that an individual shareholder is the corporation's alter ego if (1) the shareholder exerted control over the corporation, which had "no separate mind, will or existence of its own," (2) that control was used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty proximately caused the injury complained of.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Arbitration. Decision by Court of Appeals of Paris deserved recognition under principles of international comity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Aaron Carlson Corporation v. Cohen
Court: Supreme Court of Minnesota.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is an equitable remedy that is intended to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Veil-piercing claim against shareholders of judgment debtor, which was controlled by receiver, could be brought by judgment creditor.

Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The instrumentality rule, as used to determine whether piercing the corporate veil is proper, has three prongs, the first of which requires control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, second, that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and third, that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: When a corporation is so manipulated by an individual or another corporate entity as to become a mere puppet or tool for the manipulator, justice may require the courts to disregard the corporate fiction and impose liability on the real actor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Factual findings supported use of identity rule as basis for piercing corporate veil of real estate development entity.

Title: Crosskey Architects, LLC v. Poko Partners, LLC
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: When the statutory privilege of doing business in the corporate form is employed as a cloak for the evasion of obligations, as a mask behind which to do injustice, or invoked to subvert equity, the separate personality of the corporation will be disregarded.

Title: Pasco Common Condominium Association, Inc. v. Benson

Headnote: The corporate veil is ordinarily pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Takeda Pharmaceuticals U.S.A., Inc. v. Spireas
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Although a corporation normally is regarded as a legal entity separate and distinct from its shareholders under Pennsylvania law, this legal fiction of a separate corporate entity will be disregarded whenever justice or public policy demand and when the rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced nor the theory of the corporate entity rendered useless.

Title: Dao v. Faustin

Title: Dao v. Faustin

Headnote: Under Virginia law, piercing the corporate veil is justified when the unity of interest and ownership is such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist and to adhere to that separateness would work an injustice.

Title: In re Garza

Headnote: Under Texas law, legal protections to individuals who conduct their business through a corporation or limited liability company (LLC) are to be disregarded when the organization has been used as part of a unfair device to achieve an inequitable result; in such circumstances, the corporate veil may be pierced to hold the individuals personally liable.

Headnote: Under Texas law, alter ego remedy applies when there is such an identity between a corporation and an individual that all separateness between the parties has ceased, and when a failure to disregard the corporate form would be unfair or unjust.

Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and is used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The proper test to apply when an outsider seeks to reverse pierce the corporate veil is a three-part process: in part one, the outsider must first prove that, under the instrumentality and/or identity rules, as set forth in traditional veil piercing cases, the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed, if the outsider prevails on part one, then, in part two, trial courts must consider the impact of reverse piercing on innocent shareholders and creditors, and in part three, trial courts must consider whether adequate remedies at law are available.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The identity rule for piercing the corporate veil requires the plaintiff to show that there was such a unity of interest and ownership that the independence of the corporations had in effect ceased or had never begun, in which case an adherence to the fiction of separate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting the economic entity to escape liability arising out of an operation conducted by one corporation for the benefit of the whole enterprise.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Title: McKay v. Longman
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity, to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure, in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Outsider reverse veil piercing is recognized despite prospective legislative prohibition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Trujillo
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a general principle of corporate law is that shareholders of a corporation are protected against personal liability unless it be shown that the corporation is formed or used for some illegal, fraudulent or other unjust purpose which justifies piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor was equitable owner of Panamanian foundation, such that assets of foundation were property of the bankruptcy estate subject to turnover.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Brugnara Properties VI
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Veil-piercing under California law requires (1) such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of corporation and individual do not exist, and (2) that an inequitable result will follow if acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Taxing authorities could pierce veil separating taxpayers from wholly owned corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Taszarek v. Lakeview Excavating, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: Under the alter ego approach to piercing the corporate veil: there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment piercing the corporate veil contained insufficient findings to permit appellate review, and thus remand for further findings was required.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Taszarek v. Lakeview Excavating, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: An element of injustice, inequity or fundamental unfairness must be present before a court may properly pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Judgment piercing the corporate veil contained insufficient findings to permit appellate review, and thus remand for further findings was required.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kahan Jewelry Corp. v. Coin Dealer of 47th St. Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, First Department, New York.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil and hold individual defendants liable for a corporation's actions, plaintiffs are required to show that (1) the individual owners exercised complete domination over the corporation with respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff, resulting in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. In breach of contract claim, plaintiffs failed to show that individual owners of corporate defendants could be held liable for corporation's actions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Draw Another Circle.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, the decision to pierce the corporate veil generally results from a combination of several factors and an overall element of unfairness or injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Liquidating trustee stated claim against debtor's board chair for breach of fiduciary duty.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Denny v. Breawick, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Hancock County.
Headnote: Courts are to pierce the corporate veil when it would be unjust to allow the shareholders to hide behind the fiction of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractor had such complete control over his companies that they had no separate mind of their own, as necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Title: Denny v. Breawick, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third District, Hancock County.
Headnote: To satisfy second prong of test for piercing the corporate veil, a plaintiff must demonstrate that a defendant shareholder exercised control over the corporation in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act; unjust or inequitable conduct in the absence of fraud, an illegal act, or an unlawful act is not sufficient.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Contractor had such complete control over his companies that they had no separate mind of their own, as necessary to pierce corporate veil.

Title: In re Blast Fitness Group, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Massachusetts, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, doctrine of corporate disregard is an equitable tool that authorizes courts, in rare situations, to ignore corporate formalities, where such disregard is necessary to provide a meaningful remedy for injuries and to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Chapter 7 trustee stated plausible claim for veil piercing and/or alter ego determination against affiliated entities under Massachusetts law.

Title: Mattingly Law Firm, P.C. v. Henson
Court: Court of Civil Appeals of Oklahoma, Division No. 1.
Headnote: The legal fiction that a corporation is separate and distinct from its stakeholders was created to further the interests of convenience and justice; where in the context of particular facts the employment of this fiction no longer supports these ends, courts may choose to disregard it and pierce the veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Non-owner of a limited liability company (LLC) was considered equitable owner for purposes of piercing corporate veil when he controlled the LLC.

Title: Martin Hilti Family Trust v. Knoedler Gallery, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under the alter ego theory of piercing the corporate veil, a plaintiff must demonstrate a mingling of the operations of the entity and its owner plus an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Art gallery's owner was not liable to foreign trust for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act claims.

Title: Martin Hilti Family Trust v. Knoedler Gallery, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When determining whether a corporation and its dominant shareholder operate as a single economic entity, such that it may pierce corporate veil and impose liability on shareholder, a plaintiff must allege injustice or unfairness that is a result of an abuse of the corporate form, which is satisfied where corporation was used to engage in conduct that was inequitable, prohibited, an unfair trade practice, or illegal.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Art gallery's owner was not liable to foreign trust for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Martin Hilti Family Trust v. Knoedler Gallery, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: When determining whether a corporation and its dominant shareholder operate as a single economic entity, such that it may pierce corporate veil and impose liability on shareholder, a plaintiff need not prove the corporation was created with fraud or unfairness in mind; it is sufficient to prove that it was so used.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Fraudulent Transfers. Art gallery's owner was not liable to foreign trust for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act claims.

Title: Singh v. Nadlan, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Generally, piercing the corporate veil requires a showing that: (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked; and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.

Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, the corporate veil may be pierced only with reluctance and in extreme circumstances when compelled by reasons of equity.

Title: Innerimages, Inc. v. Newman

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil, a court must be convinced that the separate corporate entity is a sham or a dummy or that disregarding the separate corporate entity is necessary to accomplish justice.

Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil, under New Jersey law, is not a mechanism by which legal liability is imposed per se, but rather an equitable remedy designed to remedy a fundamental unfairness perpetrated under the guise of the corporate form.

Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In the absence of extraordinary circumstances, such as fraud or injustice, a court will generally decline to pierce the corporate veil under New Jersey law.

Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Even in instances where one individual shareholder or director dominates the corporate entity, liability generally is imposed by piercing the corporate veil, under New Jersey law, only where the dominant party has abused the privilege of incorporation by using the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud or injustice, or otherwise to circumvent the law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Real estate developer's contentions did not demonstrate that limited liability company functioned as a dummy or shell corporation.

Title: Linus Holding Corp. v. Mark Line Industries, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: In determining whether circumstances indicate that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, for purposes of piercing the corporate veil under New Jersey law, a plaintiff need not prove common law fraud but instead demonstrate that the defendants, via the corporate form, perpetrated a fraud, injustice, or the like, a less exacting standard.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Real estate developer's contentions did not demonstrate that limited liability company functioned as a dummy or shell corporation.

Title: Tisch v. Tisch
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Division III.
Headnote: A court may reverse pierce the corporate veil only upon a clear showing by the requesting party of all the following factors: (1) the controlling insider and the corporation are alter egos of each other; (2) justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship over the corporate form because the corporate form is used to perpetuate a fraud or to defeat a rightful claim; and (3) an equitable result is achieved by piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Derivative Actions. Minority shareholders of closely-held corporation sufficiently alleged claim that controlling shareholder engaged in civil theft with regard to profits not formally declared as distributions.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dailey v. Ayers Land Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: While, legally speaking, a corporation constitutes an entity separate and apart from the persons who own it, such is a fiction of the law introduced for purpose of convenience and to subserve the ends of justice; and it is now well settled, as a general principle, that the fiction should be disregarded when it is urged with an intent not within its reason and purpose, and in such a way that its retention would produce injustices or inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Joint Ventures. A genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether subdivision developer entered into a joint venture to create, develop, and market subdivision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dailey v. Ayers Land Development, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil in order to hold the shareholder(s) actively participating in the operation of the business personally liable, there is normally a two-prong test: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and of the individual shareholder(s) no longer exist, or a disregard of formalities requirement, and (2) an inequitable result would occur if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, or a fairness requirement.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Joint Ventures. A genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether subdivision developer entered into a joint venture to create, develop, and market subdivision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Cestaro
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: Connecticut courts are reluctant to pierce corporate veil and will apply that remedy only in exceptional circumstances, as, for example, when corporation is mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Shapow

Headnote: To pierce corporate veil under California law, there must be evidence of such critical facts as inadequate capitalization, commingling of assets, disregard of corporate formalities, or other facts which demonstrate the critical element, that an inequitable result would have followed if the corporate separateness had been respected.

Title: In re Shapow

Headnote: Under California law, alter ego doctrine does not guard every unsatisfied creditor of corporation, but instead affords protection where some conduct amounting to bad faith makes it inequitable for the corporate owner to hide behind the corporate form.

Title: Town–Line Car Wash, Inc. v. Don's Kleen Machine Kar Wash, Inc.

Title: Yamin v. Carroll Wayne Conn, L.P.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Howe v. Links Club Condominium Association, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To succeed in inquiry of whether a noncorporate defendant may be held liable for her personal actions as an officer or director after fact finder determines corporate veil should be pierced, plaintiffs must present evidence of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to transaction attacked so that corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Allegations by minority unit owners in condominium complex sufficiently stated claim for piercing condominium association's corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Tully v. Mirz

Title: DeWeese v. Pribyla

Title: Lunneborg v. My Fun Life
Court: Supreme Court of Idaho, Lewiston, April 2018 Term.
Headnote: In making piercing the corporate veil and alter ego equitable determinations, trial courts are free to consider a myriad of factors without resorting to a formulaic recitation of elements that must be proven as if the exercise were akin to a criminal case wherein the "elements" must be proven by the state beyond a reasonable doubt; such determinations are circumscribed in principles of "fairness" and "justice" and will be left to the discretion of trial courts to weigh the various equitable considerations and determine whether, in their discretion, a party is entitled to equitable relief.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Court could pierce corporate veil to hold sole shareholder's non-shareholder wife liable for damages award to former corporate employee.

Title: Kirk v. Schaeffler Group USA, Inc.

Title: Shantou Real Lingerie Manufacturing Co., Ltd. v. Native Group International, Ltd.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene; without a causal link between the control exerted over the corporation and the fraud or other wrong, limited liability will prevail.

Title: Estate of Rivas by and through Soto v. Fred Smith Construction, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To prove an alter ego relationship between corporate entities, a claimant must establish three things: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; and (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  Highways and Roads. Plaintiff's summary judgment evidence only gave rise to speculation that highway contractor and its affiliate were alter egos of one another.

Title: Cortlandt Street Recovery Corp. v. Bonderman
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: Generally, a plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must show that (1) the owners exercised complete domination of the corporation in respect to the transaction attacked, and (2) that such domination was used to commit a fraud or wrong against the plaintiff which resulted in plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Parties. Indenture conferred standing on trustee to bring action against private equity firms that controlled parent company of issuers and guarantor of notes.

Title: WFG National Title Insurance Company v. Meehan
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth District, Cuyahoga County.
Headnote: The current test for piercing the corporate veil in Ohio provides that the corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own; (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful conduct or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Pleading. Insurance agent's pleadings failed to address insurer's qualified immunity and aver that immunity did not apply, as was required for defamation claim.

Title: Stockdale v. Ellsworth
Court: Supreme Court of Colorado.
Headnote: If a corporation is found to be merely the alter ego of a shareholder, in determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, the court must consider whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the shareholder and corporation over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim; only when the corporate form was used to shield a dominant shareholder's improprieties may the veil be pierced.

Title: Turman v. Superior Court of Orange County
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Two requirements must be met to invoke the alter ego doctrine to disregard corporate identity: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist; and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.

Title: Curci Investments, LLC v. Baldwin
Court: Court of Appeal, Fourth District, Division 3, California.
Headnote: Before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked, on basis of a sham corporate entity having been formed for purpose of committing fraud or other misdeeds, two conditions generally must be met: first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Judgment creditor was not per se precluded from reverse piercing corporate veil to add LLC, in which judgment debtor held interest, to judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: May v. Williams
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Where a corporation or a limited liability company (LLC) is used for an improper purpose and to perpetuate injustice by which it avoids its legal obligations, equity will step in, pierce the corporate veil, and grant appropriate relief.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Damages. Award of $116,516.57 in actual damages was warranted for LLC's breach of lease agreements and oral contract for use of construction equipment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: State ex rel. Family Support Division v. Steak'm Take'm LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Missouri law permits a court to "pierce the corporate veil" where the following factors are shown: (1) control, meaning complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Trial court could pierce corporate veil of restaurant organized as LLC to find operator personally liable for debt owed to state child support division.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: United States v. TDC Management Corp.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, the ultimate principle in a veil-piercing analysis is one permitting its use to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Under alter ego theory, assets of corporation owned by judgment debtor were subject to garnishment by federal government as judgment creditor.

Title: In re Zak

Headnote: Under Tennessee law, even though corporate formalities have been observed, one may still challenge the corporate entity by showing that he has been the victim of some basically unfair device by which the corporate form of business organization has been used to achieve an inequitable result.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Tennessee law, the equities must substantially favor the party requesting relief, and the presumption of the corporation's separate identity should be set aside only with great caution.

Title: In re Glick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: There are two requirements before piercing the corporate veil: first, the court must find that the shareholder dominated the corporation to the point that it had no separate existence and was effectively his alter ego, and second, the court must conclude that failing to set aside corporate identity and hold the shareholder liable would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: In re Glick
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Two requirements must be met before an Illinois court will pierce the corporate veil: the court must find that the shareholder dominated the corporation to the point that it had no separate existence and was effectively his alter ego, and second, the court must conclude that failing to ignore corporate identity and holding the shareholder liable would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Cohen v. Schroeder

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Delaware law, it is not enough to show that an individual defendant abused the corporate form; rather, a plaintiff must also show that through that abuse, the defendant perpetrated an injustice on an innocent third party.

Title: Cohen v. Schroeder
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, it may be more difficult for a majority shareholder to deceive a fellow insider, which in turn may make it more difficult for an insider to prove the overall injustice or unfairness necessary to pursue an alter-ego claim, since in contrast to an innocent outsider, a corporate officer is more likely to have inside knowledge of the corporation's activities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing the corporate veil to impose personal liability on majority owner in small, privately-held Delaware corporation was unwarranted.

Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Connecticut's instrumentality rule, plaintiff must establish three elements by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) that shareholders so controlled corporation with respect to the transaction attacked that corporation had no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) that shareholders used this control to commit a fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) that control and wrong-doing of shareholders proximately caused plaintiff's injury.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Title: In re Rouette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut, New Haven Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Connecticut law based on application of identity rule, plaintiff must establish that there was such a unity of interest and ownership between shareholders and corporation that the independence of corporation had in effect ceased or never begun, and that an adherence to fiction of separate corporate identity would serve only to defeat justice and equity by permitting shareholders to escape liability for actions that corporation took for their economic benefit.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Corporate creditor had no claim against individual debtor-shareholders' Chapter 7 estate.

Title: Southern Shores Realty Services, Inc. v. Miller
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: General rule is that in the ordinary course of business, a corporation is treated as distinct from its shareholders; however, exceptions to the general rule of corporate insularity may be made when applying the corporate fiction would accomplish some fraudulent purpose, operate as a constructive fraud, or defeat some strong equitable claim, and those who are responsible for the existence of the corporation are, in those situations, prevented from using its separate existence to accomplish an unconscionable result.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Contracts. Owners of vacation rentals breached contracts requiring notification to management company and return of deposits for properties in foreclosure.

Title: Premier Therapy, LLC v. Childs
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Seventh District, Columbiana County.
Headnote: There are three mandatory elements to pierce the corporate veil, including (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) the control by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud, an illegal act, or a similarly unlawful act, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issue of whether guarantor of loan for purchasers of nursing home was alter ego for home such that corporate veil could be pierced was question for jury.

Title: In re Crabtree

Headnote: Minnesota courts employ two-step analysis when determining whether corporate entity is alter ego of individual, under which they first consider the relationship between the corporation and the individual, focusing on factors such as a failure to observe corporate formalities, siphoning of corporate funds by the individual, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation merely as a facade for the individual, and then consider nature of relationship between corporation and party seeking to pierce corporate veil and whether corporation has operated in a fraudulent or unjust manner toward that party.

Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence supported finding that purported principal did not have actual control over judgment debtor corporation, as could allow piercing veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Carroll
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the conditions under which the corporate form may be disregarded vary according to the facts of each case, but generally, two requirements must be established for alter ego liability to exist: (1) there must be unity of interest and ownership such that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt from debtor's failure to disclose during course of renovation project that certain subcontractors were not paid was nondischargeable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Proof of element of "fraud or wrong," as required under Michigan law in order to pierce corporate veil, is necessarily distinct from the separate, and additional, required showing that plaintiff would suffer some "unjust loss" if corporate veil were not pierced.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Transfers did not support piercing veil that separated debtor from related company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: In order to pierce corporate veil under Michigan law, plaintiff must prove some fraud or wrong going beyond merely an unjust loss to plaintiff if corporate veil is not pierced; plaintiff must establish that a controlling entity engaged in deliberate wrongful conduct that either was designed to or actually did produce injury to obligees of the instrumental entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Transfers did not support piercing veil that separated debtor from related company.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Fiction of a distinct corporate entity separate from its stockholders is a convenience introduced in the law to subserve ends of justice, and when this fiction is invoked to subvert justice, Michigan courts will ignored it.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Business Relationships. Transfers did not support piercing veil that separated debtor from related company.

Title: Lim v. Miller Parking Co.

Headnote: Under Michigan law, court sitting in equity may look through the veil of corporate structure, that is, pierce the corporate veil, in order to avoid fraud or injustice.

Headnote: Prior to piercing corporate veil, Michigan court must determine whether the fraud or wrong that supports veil-piercing claim would cause plaintiff to suffer an unjust loss.

Title: Agai v. Diontech Consulting, Inc.
