Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Alter ego doctrine is intended to prevent the legal separation between corporation and its controlling shareholder or shareholders from being used to perpetuate an injustice on third parties.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Estate could not be increased on veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: Under Utah law, second prong of alter ego test, i.e., that observance of corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or lead to inequitable result, is addressed to conscience of the court, and the circumstances under which it will be met will vary with each case; however, second prong of the test is not met simply because observing the integrity of corporation would in some way prevent creditor of controlling shareholder from quickly being made whole, or because existence of corporate form is inconvenient for creditor seeking to pursue shareholder's assets.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Estate could not be increased on veil-piercing theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: 612 Wortman, LLC v. Varsity Bus Co., Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: While complete domination of the corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil, especially when the owners use the corporation as a mere device to further their personal rather than the corporate business, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. In contract action, recovering damages from individual defendants was unwarranted under trust fund doctrine or doctrine of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: M.J. v. Wisan
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: Because veil-piercing is an equitable remedy, it is available only where it is in the interest of justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Utah law allows reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: M.J. v. Wisan
Court: Supreme Court of Utah.
Headnote: A claimant seeking to impose reverse-piercing liability on a corporate entity or trust must establish not only an abuse of the corporate form, but also that such abuse resulted in fraud or injustice, and that reverse piercing is necessary to avoid an injustice, or in other words, that the claimant lacks an adequate remedy at law.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Utah law allows reverse piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >

Headnote: Indiana courts hesitate to pierce the corporate veil, but will do so to prevent fraud or injustice to a third party.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Stenlund v. Marriott International, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Maryland, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, although the courts will, in a proper case, disregard the corporate entity and deal with substance rather than form, as though a corporation did not exist, shareholders generally are not held individually liable for obligations of a corporation except where it is necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Franchises and Dealerships. Hotel franchisor was not liable for hotel guest's injuries at on-site casino based on actual agency theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: First Natl. Bank of Omaha v. iBeam Solutions, L.L.C.
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth District, Franklin County.
Headnote: The corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for wrongs committed by the corporation when (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issue of whether to pierce corporate veil of public corporation was for jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: McBeth v. Porges

Headnote: A lawsuit's underlying cause of action, by itself, does not supply the necessary fraud or injustice under the test for piercing the corporate veil under an alter-ego theory under Delaware law.

Title: Aldmyr Systems, Inc. v. Friedman

Headnote: While a district court must exercise caution when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil and exercise jurisdiction over an individual that controls a corporate entity, after a careful review of the facts and circumstances of the particular case, courts will not hesitate to take such action when justice so requires.

Title: Open Door Foods, LLC v. Pasta Machines, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, which permits, in some circumstances, the imposition of personal liability on owners for the obligations or wrongs of their corporation, requires that the party seeking to invoke it demonstrate that a court in equity should intervene because the owners of a corporation exercised complete domination over it in the transaction at issue and, in doing so, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, thereby perpetrating a wrong that resulted in injury to the plaintiff.

Title: Overton v. Art Finance Partners LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: With respect to the second requirement for piercing the corporate veil under Delaware law, an overall element of injustice or unfairness, the injustice must consist of more than merely the tort or breach of contract that is the basis of the plaintiff's lawsuit; effectively, the corporation must be a sham and exist for no other purpose than as a vehicle for fraud.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW  Consignments. Art dealer's transfer of one painting to lender as collateral for a loan did not constitute a consignment.

Title: American Federated Title Corp. v. GFI Management Services, Inc.

Title: Pister v. State, Dept. of Revenue
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: With regard to the first element for piercing the corporate veil under Washington law, namely, that the corporate form was used to violate or evade a duty, the court must find an abuse of the corporate form, which typically involves fraud, misrepresentation, or some form of manipulation of the corporation to the stockholder's benefit and creditor's detriment.

Title: Pister v. State, Dept. of Revenue
Court: Supreme Court of Alaska.
Headnote: With regard to the second element for piercing the corporate veil under Washington law, namely, that the corporate veil must be disregarded in order to prevent loss to an innocent party, wrongful corporate activities must actually harm the party seeking relief so that disregard is necessary and intentional misconduct must be the cause of the harm that is avoided by disregard.

Title: In re Miller Parking Co., LLC

Headnote: Under Michigan law, an alter ego claim is not, by itself, a cause of action; rather, it is a doctrine which fastens liability on the individual who uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct his or her own personal business, with such liability arising from fraud or injustice perpetuated not on the corporation, but on third persons dealing with the corporation.

Title: Kain Development, LLC v. Krause Properties, LLC
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Third Department, New York.
Headnote: Absent fraud, the corporate veil may be pierced in order to achieve equity when a corporation has been so dominated by individuals or other entities that it primarily transacts the dominators' business instead of its own; this inquiry includes consideration of factors such as the overlap in ownership, officers, directors and personnel, the capitalization of the corporation, any commingling of assets and the presence, or absence, of the formalities that attend the corporate form.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Vendor and Purchaser. Purchaser repudiated, rather than terminated, contract for sale of real property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Nicks v. Nicks
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, a party must satisfy three elements, including: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: FAMILY LAW - Spousal Support. Trial court did not abuse discretion, when determining alimony, by reducing wife's purportedly reasonable monthly expenses.

Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.

Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: Actions to pierce the corporate veil rest on an equitable doctrine used by courts to look past the corporate form and impose liability upon those who control the corporation, be they individuals or other corporations, when they create or use the corporate form to accomplish a fraud, injustice, or some unlawful purpose.

Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, DIVISION ONE.
Headnote: A court will disregard the corporate form and hold the corporate owners or officers liable if three elements are met: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: INSURANCE  Title. Res judicata barred title insurer's fraud and negligence claims against home builder that misrepresented that subcontractors had been paid.

Title: Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company v. Miceli

Title: In re Carrano
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Connecticut.
Headnote: Under Connecticut law, to pierce the corporate veil pursuant to the "instrumentality rule" requires, in any case but an express agency, proof of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) that such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest or unjust act in contravention of the plaintiff's legal rights, and (3) that the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt for overpayment of rent fell within the discharge exception for debts obtained through embezzlement.

Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under New York law, while complete domination of a corporation is the key to piercing the corporate veil, such domination, standing alone, is not enough; some showing of a wrongful or unjust act toward plaintiff is required.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under New York law, party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Lothrop v. North American Air Charter, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, gross inequity that can lead to the piercing of the corporate veil typically requires some finding that the corporation engaged in misconduct through the corporate form.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. District court could not exercise personal jurisdiction over defendant under alter-ego theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Deschepper v. Midwest Wine and Spirits, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Illinois law: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) adhering to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or promote inequitable consequences.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Independent Contractors. Factors favored finding that, under FLSA, workers for liquor wholesaler were employees, rather than independent contractors.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Bull
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: In order for moving party to prevail on veil-piercing claim under New York law, party's evidence must show that individual used his control over corporation to commit a wrongful or unjust act specifically directed at moving party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate creditor had no veil-piercing claim in individual Chapter 11 case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Bull
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Florida, Jacksonville Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, courts are permitted to disregard corporate form and to pierce corporate veil only in the most extraordinary cases; simply stated, veil piercing is equitable remedy that is used to prevent fraudulent or improper use of corporate form from injuring the party seeking to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Corporate creditor had no veil-piercing claim in individual Chapter 11 case.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: S.M. v. Oxford Health Plans (N.Y.), Inc.
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: As a matter of contract law, New York courts will only pierce the corporate veil to prevent fraud or other wrong, or where a parent dominates and controls a subsidiary.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Health plan administrator's medical necessity determination regarding IVIG treatment was not arbitrary and capricious.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Opus East, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Merely presenting evidence of dominion or control of parent over the subsidiary, without evidence of fraud or similar injustice, will not support alter ego liability under Delaware law; rather, party seeking to pierce corporate veil must prove that defendants used corporate form to defeat the ends of justice, to perpetuate fraud, to accomplish a crime, or otherwise to evade the law.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Veil could not be pierced to augment estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Opus East, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: Element of fraud or injustice needed under Delaware law in order to pierce corporate veil must be found in defendants' use of corporate form itself.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Bankruptcy Estate. Veil could not be pierced to augment estate.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Omega Demolition Corp. v. Hays Group, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, piercing the corporate veil is an equitable remedy that may be applied in order to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Parties. Client's action against insurance broker's parent could not proceed in equity and good conscience among existing parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Stanley v. Liberty
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil to hold a corporate officer or director personally liable for the actions of a corporation must demonstrate that: (1) the officer or director abused the privilege of a separate corporate identity; and (2) an unjust or inequitable result would occur if the court recognized the separate corporate existence.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Arbitration. Closely held corporations and owner were not entitled to vacation of arbitration award in favor of former executive on breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Stanley v. Liberty
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Maine.
Headnote: Although law imposes more stringent standards for piercing the corporate veil in contractual disputes, the corporate veil can nonetheless be pierced when the evidence supports a finding that the corporation is merely an alter ego of an individual and when necessary in the interests of justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Arbitration. Closely held corporations and owner were not entitled to vacation of arbitration award in favor of former executive on breach of contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Fed. Ins. Co. v. Fredericks
Court: Court of Appeals of Ohio, Second District, Montgomery County.
Headnote: For a court to disregard the corporate form, (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable must be so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable must be exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss must have resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Sister companies and holding company were not third-party beneficiaries to property owner's construction contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Meridian North Investments LP v. Sondhi
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Courts are reluctant to disregard a corporate entity, but will do so to prevent fraud or unfairness to third parties.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Provision of lease for office building that president signed purporting to absolve lessor from liability for injuries to tenants did not apply to president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Powertrain, Inc. v. Ma
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Mississippi, Aberdeen Division.
Headnote: The possibility that a plaintiff may have difficulty enforcing a judgment is not an injustice warranting piercing the corporate veil under Mississippi law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Digby Adler Group LLC v. Image Rent a Car, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the alter ego doctrine arises when a plaintiff claims that an opposing party is using the corporate form unjustly and in derogation of the plaintiff's interests, such that the court should disregard the corporate entity and hold the individual shareholders liable for the actions of the corporation.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Internet. Award of $25,000 in statutory damages was appropriate in van rental service's cybersquatting suit against two competing companies.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Digby Adler Group LLC v. Image Rent a Car, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, there are two general requirements for piercing the corporate veil: (1) that there be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) that, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: TRADEMARKS  Internet. Award of $25,000 in statutory damages was appropriate in van rental service's cybersquatting suit against two competing companies.

Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, the "alter ego doctrine" arises when a plaintiff comes into court claiming that an opposing party is using the corporate form unjustly and in derogation of the plaintiff's interests.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Gerritsen v. Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc.
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, before the alter ego doctrine can be invoked, two elements must be alleged: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Author failed to allege that there was a contract between her and entertainment company that produced film allegedly based on her novel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: AZTE, Inc. v. Auto Collection, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The doctrine of "piercing the corporate veil" is an exception to the general rule that a corporation exists independently of its owners, who are not personally liable for its obligations, and allows the imposition of individual liability on owners for the obligations of their corporation to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Owner of corporation exercised domination and control warranting piercing of corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Bash v. Textron Financial Corp.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, corporate form may be disregarded and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Debtor was operated as Ponzi scheme, as required for Ponzi scheme presumption of fraudulent intent to arise in trustee's action to avoid and recover transfers.

Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The "Norman test" is a two-part test to determine when a party in a breach of contract action against a corporation may pierce the corporate veil and obtain judgment against individual shareholders; the first part of the test, often called the "formalities requirement", requires the movant to show such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and the second part of the test, often called the "fairness requirement", requires the movant to show that observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or condone an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Title: Lodges at Bear Hollow Condominium Homeowners Ass'n, Inc. v. Bear Hollow Restoration, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Utah.
Headnote: The possibility that a plaintiff may have difficulty enforcing a judgment against a corporate entity alone is not the type of injustice that warrants piercing the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Homeowners association failed to demonstrate that developer and general contractor were alter egos.

Title: DBT Yuma, L.L.C. v. Yuma County Airport Authority
Court: Court of Appeals of Arizona, Division 1.
Headnote: For one corporate entity to be the alter ego of another, as could support imposition of vicarious liability on the other, plaintiffs must show evidence of unity of control, that observance of alleged alter ego's corporate form would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, and that the individuality or separateness of the two has ceased to exist.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT - Municipalities. Statute providing that airport authority functions as agency of county did not impose vicarious liability on county.

Title: Gilman v. Walters

Headnote: In order to establish that corporation is merely alter ego, two showings must be made: first, there must be such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; and second, circumstances must be such that adherence to fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Gilman v. Walters
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Indiana, Evansville Division.
Headnote: Piercing corporate veil is appropriate if corporation is mere shell, serving no legitimate business purpose, and used primarily as intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Arbitration. Arbitration clause indicated parties' intent to confer on arbitrator authority to determine his own jurisdiction.

Title: Rutherlan Enterprises, Inc. v. Zettler Hardware
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Pursuant to Ohio law, there is a three-prong test for the Court to determine whether veil piercing is proper in a particular case, and the court may disregard the corporate form and hold individual shareholders liable for corporate misdeeds if: (1) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that the corporation has no separate mind, will, or existence of its own, (2) control over the corporation by those to be held liable was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against the person seeking to disregard the corporate entity, and (3) injury or unjust loss resulted to the plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Limitations. Savings clause in Ohio's four-year statute of limitations for fraud claims did not operate to toll limitations period.

Title: GreenHunter Energy, Inc. v. Western Ecosystems Technology, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Wyoming.
Headnote: No single category, except fraud, alone justifies a decision to disregard the veil of limited liability; rather, there must be some combination of them, and of course an injustice or unfairness must always be proven. West's Wyo.Stat.Ann. § 17–29–104(a).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing limited liability company's veil to impose liability on sole member for debt to consulting firm was warranted despite absence of fraud in the classic sense.

Title: In re Geer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Concept of piercing the corporate veil is applied in Georgia to remedy injustices which arise where a party has overextended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud, or evade contractual or tort responsibility.

Title: In re Geer
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, the alter ego and veil piercing doctrines are used as remedies for inequitable conduct which allow corporate creditors to pursue individual shareholders on corporate debts; the doctrines do not invalidate the corporate existence except for purposes of a particular creditor's debt collection.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's transfer of interest in house to QRPT did not warrant denial of his discharge.

Title: Saletech, LLC v. East Balt, Inc.
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Third Division.
Headnote: Courts will pierce the corporate veil where: (1) a unity of interest and ownership appears so strong that the separate personalities of the corporation and the parties who compose it no longer exist, and (2) under the circumstances, adhering to the fiction of a separate corporation would promote injustice or inequitable circumstances.

Title: Queens West Development Corp. v. Nixbot Realty Associates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Although one of the primary legitimate purposes of incorporating is to limit or eliminate the personal liability of corporate principals, the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil allows a corporation's separate legal existence to be disregarded to prevent fraud and achieve equity.

Title: Queens West Development Corp. v. Nixbot Realty Associates
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil must demonstrate that a court in equity should intervene because the owners of the corporation exercised complete domination over it in the transaction at issue and, in doing so, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form, thereby perpetrating a wrong that resulted in injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Eminent Domain. In condemnation proceeding, just compensation for taking trade fixtures was warranted, separate from award for taking of fee.

Title: Pencheng Si v. Laogai Research Foundation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, a two-pronged test is used to determine whether to pierce the corporate veil, asking: (1) whether there such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) whether, if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.

Title: In re LLS America, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Washington.
Headnote: Under Washington law, to disregard corporate entity and assess liability against shareholders in corporation, corporate form must be intentionally used to violate or evade duty, and disregard must be necessary and required to present unjustified loss to injured party.

Title: ERB Poultry, Inc. v. CEME, L.L.C.

Title: Toumazou v. Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus

Title: In re McCauley

Headnote: Under Utah law, the alter ego doctrine is intended to prevent the legal separation between the corporation and the controlling shareholder or shareholders from being used to perpetuate an injustice on third parties.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re McCauley
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Utah.
Headnote: To invoke the alter ego doctrine under Utah law, there must be a concurrence of two circumstances: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, viz., the corporation is, in fact, the alter ego of one or a few individuals; and (2) the observance of the corporate form would sanction a fraud, promote injustice, or an inequitable result would follow.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Trustee failed to establish that limited liability company (LLC) belonged to debtor based on alter ego theory under Utah law.

Title: John Knox Village v. Fortis Const. Co., LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Where a corporation is used for an improper purpose and to perpetrate injustice by which it avoids its legal obligations, equity will step in, pierce the corporate veil and grant appropriate relief.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Substantial evidence supported piercing corporate veil to hold general contractor's owners individually liable for fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: John Knox Village v. Fortis Const. Co., LLC
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate entity and hold corporate owners liable for the corporation's wrongful acts if the following three elements are established: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the corporation to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Substantial evidence supported piercing corporate veil to hold general contractor's owners individually liable for fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Liberty Synergistics, Inc. v. Microflo Ltd.

Headnote: If the domination requirement for piercing the corporate veil under New York law is met, the plaintiff must then show: (1) the existence of a wrongful or unjust act toward that party, and (2) that the act caused the party's harm.

Headnote: The party seeking to pierce the corporate veil under New York law must establish that the owners of the corporation, through their dominance of the corporation, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.

Title: In re Joseph Walker & Company, Inc.

Headnote: Under South Carolina law, in an appropriate case and in furtherance of the ends of justice, the corporate veil will be pierced and the corporation and its stockholders will be treated as identical.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Representations made by debtor's dual director concerning debtor's ability to perform contract did not rise to level of actionable fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Joseph Walker & Company, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. South Carolina.
Headnote: Under South Carolina law, two-prong DeWitt test is used in analyzing whether to pierce an entity's corporate veil and impose personal liability on its directors: the first part of the test looks to observance of corporate formalities by dominant shareholders, considering eight factors, including whether (1) there is evidence that corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (2) corporate formalities were not observed, (3) dividends were not paid, (4) corporation was insolvent, (5) corporate funds were siphoned off by controlling shareholders, (6) corporate records were not maintained, (7) corporation was a facade for the operations of controlling shareholders, and (8) there are non-functioning or "frozen out" shareholders or directors, while second part of test requires that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if the acts of the corporation are not regarded as the acts of the individuals.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Claims. Representations made by debtor's dual director concerning debtor's ability to perform contract did not rise to level of actionable fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Flame S.A. v. Industrial Carriers, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Virginia, Norfolk Division.
Headnote: No one single factor can support an alter ego finding, but the factor of injustice or fundamental unfairness is the most important in an alter ego analysis.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Attachment. Defendants lacked minimum contacts with forum for exercise of personal jurisdiction in admiralty action involving attachment of a vessel.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Intelligent Direct Marketing
Court: United States District Court, E.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, alter ego applies when: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and the individual or organization controlling it that their separate personalities no longer exist, and (2) failure to disregard the corporate entity would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Corporation was alter ego of debtor corporation under California law.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Takiguchi v. MRI Intern., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: To hold an individual liable under an alter ego theory, under Nevada law, the plaintiffs must show: (1) the corporation was influenced and governed by the person asserted to be the alter ego; (2) there is such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other; and (3) the facts are such that adherence to the corporate fiction of a separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION - Fraud. Investors sufficiently pled that they made domestic transactions in securities not listed on a domestic exchange.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Blanks v. Fluor Corp.
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Eastern District, Division Four.
Headnote: The theory of the alter ego has been adopted by the courts to prevent injustice, in those cases where the fiction of a corporate entity has been used as a subterfuge to defeat public convenience or to perpetrate a wrong; it should never be invoked to work an injustice, or to give an unfair advantage.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Parent company's domination of and control of subsidiaries were insufficient to establish principal-agent relationship.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Hyungkeun Sun
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Colorado.
Headnote: Under Colorado law, piercing the corporate veil is appropriate when three elements are present: (1) the corporation was a mere alter ego of the shareholder, (2) the corporate structure was used to perpetrate a wrong, and (3) piercing the corporate veil would achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY  Discharge. Debt arising from creditors' investment with debtors was nondischargeable.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Howland
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Lexington Division.
Headnote: Kentucky courts pierce the corporate veil sparingly and only when necessary to prevent injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee could not reverse veil-pierce in support of fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Howland
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Lexington Division.
Headnote: To successfully pierce corporate veil under Kentucky law, plaintiff must prove loss of separate entity existence and an injustice beyond mere inability to collect debt from corporation; however, proof of actual fraud is not required.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Trustee could not reverse veil-pierce in support of fraudulent transfer claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kutty v. U.S. Dept. of Labor
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, corporate identity may be disregarded and owners of stock and assets may be treated as identical to corporation upon showing that it is sham or dummy or where necessary to accomplish justice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold medical clinic operator personally liable for immigration violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Kutty v. U.S. Dept. of Labor
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Sixth Circuit.
Headnote: Tennessee law allows piercing of corporate veil only where control over corporation has been used to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetuate violation of statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of third parties' rights.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing of corporate veil was warranted to hold medical clinic operator personally liable for immigration violations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Geanacopulos v. Narconon Fresh Start
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Nevada courts will find a corporate defendant liable under an alter ego theory if the plaintiff proves three factors by a preponderance of the evidence: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego; (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other; and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Tort Liability. Patient sufficiently alleged that licensor and sub-licensor of drug counseling facility's trademark were responsible his mistreatment under alter ego or agency theory.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hammett v. Atcheson
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: Where a corporation or a limited liability company (LLC) is used for an improper purpose and to perpetuate injustice by which it avoids its legal obligations, equity will step in, pierce the corporate veil, and grant appropriate relief.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Overturned verdict on one of several theories of liability for which damages were unapportioned required new trial on damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hammett v. Atcheson
Court: Missouri Court of Appeals, Western District.
Headnote: For a court to disregard the business entity or pierce the corporate veil, a plaintiff must demonstrate the following three-pronged test: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Damages. Overturned verdict on one of several theories of liability for which damages were unapportioned required new trial on damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Simons v. Ditto Trade, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Illinois law governing the alter ego doctrine, plaintiff must plead both a unity of interest and ownership, and facts which show that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: SECURITIES REGULATION  Fraud. Former chief executive officer failed to state claims for securities fraud and control person liability under Securities Exchange Age.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Soule v. High Rock Holding, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. Nevada.
Headnote: Nevada courts apply the alter ego doctrine where the following requirements are met: (1) the corporation must be influenced and governed by the person asserted to be its alter ego, (2) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that one is inseparable from the other, and (3) the facts must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate entity would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice; it is not necessary that the plaintiff prove actual fraud, rather, it is enough if the recognition of the two entities as separate would result in an injustice.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. The Bankruptcy Court abused its discretion in denying a creditor's request for additional time for discovery under summary judgment rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. Federal Resources Corp.
Court: United States District Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, the corporate veil may be pierced when (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality of such corporation and such person has ceased and (2) it appears from the facts that the observance of the fiction of separate existence would, under the circumstances, sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: ENVIRONMENTAL LAW - CERCLA. Response action taken by government under CERCLA was consistent with national contingency plan.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. Boyce
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: California law recognizes alter ego liability where two conditions are met: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the individuality, or separateness, of said person and corporation has ceased, and (2) adherence to the fiction of the separate existence of the corporation would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Transferee was nominee of taxpayer, for purposes of enforcing federal tax lien.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. Boyce
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, traditional piercing of the corporate veil is justified as an equitable remedy when the shareholders have abused the corporate form to evade individual liability, circumvent a statute, or accomplish a wrongful purpose.
Document Preview: TAXATION - Collection. Transferee was nominee of taxpayer, for purposes of enforcing federal tax lien.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Al Rushaid v. National Oilwell Varco, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law, the limitation on liability afforded by the corporate structure can be ignored only when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result, such as when the corporate structure has been abused to perpetuate a fraud, evade an existing obligation, achieve or perpetuate a monopoly, circumvent a statute, protect a crime, or justify wrong.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ralls Corp. v. Huerfano River Wind, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Newnan Division.
Headnote: Georgia courts will disregard the corporate form if a corporation is a mere alter ego or business conduit of a person and the corporate form was used as a subterfuge so that to observe it would work an injustice.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Creditor's allegations stated a fraud claim against LLC that owned debtor and debtor's president under Georgia Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Ralls Corp. v. Huerfano River Wind, LLC
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Georgia, Newnan Division.
Headnote: Under Georgia law, piercing the corporate veil is used to remedy injustices which arise where a party has over extended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetuate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Creditor's allegations stated a fraud claim against LLC that owned debtor and debtor's president under Georgia Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act (UFTA).

Title: William v. AES Corp.

Headnote: While the decision to pierce the corporate veil must be taken reluctantly and cautiously, courts will not hesitate to take such action when justice so requires.

Title: Glenn v. TPI Petroleum, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: As a general proposition, the law treats a corporation as an entirely separate entity This fiction is a convenience, introduced to serve the ends of justice; however, when this fiction is invoked to subvert justice, it may be ignored by the courts.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked limited personal jurisdiction over non-resident petroleum company in negligence action.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Glenn v. TPI Petroleum, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Michigan.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, the corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another entity or individual, the corporate entity must be used to commit a fraud or wrong, and there must have been an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: TORTS - Jurisdiction. Trial court lacked limited personal jurisdiction over non-resident petroleum company in negligence action.

Title: Chiquita Fresh North America, LLC v. Long Island Banana Corp.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Determination of alter-ego liability is a fact-intensive inquiry, whose primary concerns are (1) whether the entities in question operated as a single economic entity, and (2) whether there was an overall element of injustice or unfairness.

Title: United States ex rel. Landis v. Tailwind Sports Corporation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Courts apply a two-pronged test when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil, evaluating several factors by grouping them into two questions: (1) whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) whether an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator and government stated claim against former lead rider of professional cycling team under reverse false claims provision of False Claims Act.

Title: United States ex rel. Landis v. Tailwind Sports Corporation
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Essence of the fairness prong of the two-pronged test for determining whether to pierce the corporate veil is simply that an individual businessman cannot hide from the normal consequences of carefree entrepreneuring by doing so through a corporate shell.
Document Preview: GOVERNMENT  False Claims. Relator and government stated claim against former lead rider of professional cycling team under reverse false claims provision of False Claims Act.

Title: Hasso v. Hapke

Headnote: In California, two conditions must be met before the alter ego doctrine will be invoked: (1) there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and (2) there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.

Title: Wandering Trails, LLC v. Big Bite Excavation, Inc.

Headnote: To prove that a company is the alter ego of a member of the company, a claimant must demonstrate (1) a unity of interest and ownership to a degree that the separate personalities of the company and individual no longer exist and (2) if the acts are treated as acts of the company an inequitable result would follow.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Issues of alter ego and veil-piercing claims are equitable questions.

Title: In re Lehmann

Title: Nieto-Vincenty v. Valledor

Title: Llewellyn-Jones v. Metro Property Group, LLC

Title: Buckley v. Abuzir

Headnote: Illinois courts will pierce the corporate veil where (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the parties who compose it no longer exist, and (2) circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporation would promote injustice or inequitable circumstances.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors were not required to show that controller was a shareholder in order to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Buckley v. Abuzir
Court: Appellate Court of Illinois, First District, Fourth Division.
Headnote: When considering whether the circumstances are such that adherence to the fiction of a separate corporation would promote injustice or inequitable circumstances, the court considering a request to pierce the corporate veil must ask whether there is some unfairness, such as fraud or deception, or the existence of a compelling public interest that justifies piercing.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Creditors were not required to show that controller was a shareholder in order to pierce the corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Green v. Freeman
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: To hold a defendant personally liable for the actions of a corporation, a plaintiff must present evidence of three elements: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances, but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or a dishonest and unjust act in contravention of a plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Chairperson's delegation of authority to her son did not create agency relationship between herself personally and her son.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sandoval v. Ali
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: "Equitable alter ego doctrine," which governs whether two separate entities may be treated as the same entity under California law, applies where (1) such a unity of interest and ownership exists that the personalities of the corporation and individual are no longer separate, and (2) an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT  Hours and Wages. Res judicata did not bar employees' putative class claims against employers, alleging violations FLSA and California's Unfair Competition Law (UCL).

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: A&M Global Management Corp. v. Northtown Urology Associates, P.C.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, New York.
Headnote: The burden of establishing that the corporate veil should be pierced is a heavy one, but broadly speaking, the courts will disregard the corporate form, or, to use accepted terminology, pierce the corporate veil, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.

Headnote: Courts consider overall equitable principles when determining whether corporate veil may be pierced.

Title: Trinity Industries Leasing Company v. Midwest Gas Storage, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Illinois, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, to pierce the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, corporation need not have been created with fraud or unfairness in mind, nor must plaintiff prove actual fraud, so long as it shows a mingling of the operations of the corporation and its owner plus an overall element of injustice or unfairness.
Document Preview: TORTS  Fraud. lessor alleged with sufficient particularity affirmative misrepresentations by the lessee's chief executive officer (CEO).

Title: Webmediabrands, Inc. v. Latinvision, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court, New York County, New York.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, the movant must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.

Title: Lopes v. JetsetDC, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: In the District of Columbia, generally, the corporate entity will be respected, but a party may be permitted to pierce the corporate veil upon proof, that there is: (1) unity of ownership and interest, and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetrate fraud or wrong, or other considerations of justice and equity justify it.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Complaint stated claim for piercing the corporate veil.

Title: Lopes v. JetsetDC, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under Maryland law, court may pierce the corporate veil only to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Limited Liability Companies. Complaint stated claim for piercing the corporate veil.

Title: In re Dott Acquisition, LLC
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Michigan, Southern Division.
Headnote: Under Michigan law, a court may find that one entity is the alter ego of another and pierce the corporate veil upon proof of three elements: (1) the corporate entity must be a mere instrumentality of another, (2) the corporate entity must be used to commit a fraud or wrong, and (3) there must have been an unjust loss or injury to the plaintiff.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Fact issues precluded summary judgment on trustee's preferential transfer claim.

Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil may only recover from a shareholder if the party proves by a preponderance of the evidence that: (1) the corporate form was so ignored, controlled or manipulated that it was merely the instrumentality of another, and (2) that the misuse of the corporate form would constitute a fraud or promote injustice. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).

Title: Country Contractors, Inc. v. A Westside Storage of Indianapolis, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: In order for the corporate veil to be pierced, the fraud or injustice alleged by the party seeking to pierce the veil must be caused by, or result from, misuse of the corporate form. West's A.I.C. 23–1–26–3(b).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Evidence did not support finding that contractor corporation was undercapitalized, as would support piercing corporate veil.

Title: Dog House Investments, LLC v. Teal Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Western Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: A party seeking to pierce the corporate veil bears the burden of demonstrating that the separate corporate entity is a sham or dummy or that disregarding the separate corporate entity is necessary to accomplish justice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dog House Investments, LLC v. Teal Properties, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee, Western Section, at Nashville.
Headnote: When determining whether piercing the corporate veil is appropriate, the court must consider whether the corporate entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy and also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lease provision delineating landlord's obligations for damage to premises from fire or other cause encompassed flood damage.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Dog House Investments, LLC v. Teal Properties, Inc.

Headnote: In considering a request to pierce the corporate veil, the equities must substantially favor the party requesting the court to disregard the corporate status.

Title: Rock Ivy Holding, LLC v. RC Properties, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: When applicable, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard the corporate veil include not only whether the entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also: (1) whether there was a failure to collect paid in capital; (2) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized; (3) the nonissuance of stock certificates; (4) the sole ownership of stock by one individual; (5) the use of the same office or business location; (6) the employment of the same employees or attorneys; (7) the use of the corporation as an instrumentality or business conduit for an individual or another corporation; (8) the diversion of corporate assets by or to a stockholder or other entity to the detriment of creditors, or the manipulation of assets and liabilities in another; (9) the use of the corporation as a subterfuge in illegal transactions; (10) the formation and use of the corporation to transfer to it the existing liability of another person or entity; and (11) the failure to maintain arms length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. President of LLC did not violate his duty of loyalty in seeking to sell LLC's property.

Title: Snapp v. Castlebrook Builders, Inc.

Title: Kubican v. The Tavern, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: While, legally speaking, a corporation constitutes an entity separate and apart from the persons who own it, such is a fiction of the law introduced for purpose of convenience and to subserve the ends of justice; as a general principle, that the fiction should be disregarded when it is urged with an intent not within its reason and purpose, and in such a way that its retention would produce injustices or inequitable consequences.

Title: Kubican v. The Tavern, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia.
Headnote: To "pierce the corporate veil" in order to hold a corporation's shareholders actively participating in the operation of the business personally liable, a two-prong test applies: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and of the individual shareholders no longer exist, i.e., a disregard of formalities requirement, and (2) an inequitable result would occur if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, i.e., a fairness requirement.

Title: Columbia Asset Recovery Group, LLC v. Kelly

Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law relating to the piercing of the corporate veil, the limitation on liability that the corporate structure affords can be ignored when the corporate form has been used as part of a basically unfair device to achieve an inequitable result. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Transfer of interest in debtor company's successor was fraudulent transfer under Texas Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Spring Street Partners-IV, L.P. v. Lam
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit.
Headnote: Under Texas law's doctrine of constructive fraud, neither fraud nor an intent to defraud need be shown as a prerequisite to piercing the corporate veil and disregarding the corporate entity; it is sufficient if recognizing the separate corporate existence would bring about an inequitable result. V.T.C.A., Business Organizations Code § 21.223.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Transfer of interest in debtor company's successor was fraudulent transfer under Texas Uniform Fraudulent Transfer Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Reuter
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, W.D. Missouri.
Headnote: "Alter ego doctrine" fastens liability on individual who uses a corporation merely as an instrumentality to conduct his own personal business, and such liability arises from fraud or injustice perpetrated not on the corporation but on third persons dealing with the corporation; corporate form may be disregarded only where equity requires the action to assist a third party.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Bankruptcy Estate. Debtor's powers as co-trustee of revocable trusts were estate property.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Houng
Court: United States District Court, C.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, one of the prerequisites to a finding of alter ego liability is that the corporate form must have been used to perpetrate a fraud or accomplish some other inequitable purpose.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Judgment. Arbitrator necessarily decided that debtor breached a fiduciary duty owed to judgment creditor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Anderson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Western Division,
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil under Ohio law, plaintiff must demonstrate: (1) that control over corporation by those to be held liable was so complete that corporation had no separate mind; (2) that this control was exercised in such a manner as to commit fraud or an illegal act against person seeking to disregard the corporate entity; and (3) that injury or unjust loss resulted to plaintiff from such control and wrong.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Avoidance. Statute of limitations on avoidance claim was equitably tolled.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Solid Comfort, Inc. v. Hatchett Hospitality Inc.

Headnote: Before a court may properly pierce the corporate veil, an element of injustice, inequity or fundamental unfairness must also be present.

Title: World Class Const. Management Group v. Baylor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: District of Columbia law allows plaintiffs to pierce the corporate veil rarely and on a case-by-case basis when the facts demonstrate that there is: (1) unity of ownership and interest and (2) use of the corporate form to perpetuate fraud or wrong, or other considerations of justice and equity justify it.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. A fact issue existed as to whether escrow agent released funds without authorization precluding summary judgment.

Title: Brown Bark III, L.P. v. Haver
