Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS  Attorney Fees. Unilateral attorney fee provision was not made reciprocal by statute to extent that it applied to tort claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wellness Intern. Network, Ltd. v. Sharif
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, there are two showings that must be made to establish that a corporation is merely an alter ego: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) circumstances must be such that an adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Brown v. Knowles

Headnote: Veil-piercing is an equitable doctrine, premised on the court's ability to look past the legal fiction to do equity.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Lipsitt v. Plaud
Court: Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts, Worcester.
Headnote: The doctrine of corporate disregard is an equitable tool that is only to be employed by courts in rare situations, to ignore corporate formalities, where such disregard is necessary to provide a meaningful remedy for injuries and to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. The Wage Act does not preempt common-law claims for breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims in actions to recover unpaid wages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Taurus IP, LLC v. DaimlerChrysler Corp.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Federal Circuit.
Headnote: Under Wisconsin law, the alter ego doctrine requires proof of: (1) control, not mere majority or complete stock control, but complete domination, not only of finances but of policy and business practice in respect to the transaction attacked so that the corporate entity as to this transaction had at the time no separate mind, will or existence of its own; (2) such control must have been used by the defendant to commit fraud or wrong, to perpetrate the violation of a statutory or other positive legal duty, or dishonest and unjust act in contravention of plaintiff's legal rights; and (3) the aforesaid control and breach of duty must proximately cause the injury or unjust loss complained of.
Document Preview: PATENTS - Attorney Fees. Patentee's infringement suit was exceptional, warranting award of attorney fees.

Title: Michaels v. Banks

Title: Alonso v. Blackstone Financial Group LLC

Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Debt Collection. Director of debt collection agency was debt collector within meaning of Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Habjan v. Habjan

Headnote: The legal fiction that a corporation is a legal entity separate and distinct from its shareholders will be disregarded whenever justice or public policy require and where rights of innocent parties are not prejudiced nor the theory of the corporate entity rendered useless.

Title: Phillips v. Reed Group, Ltd.

Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Colorado law, plaintiff must show that: (1) the corporate entity is the alter ego of the shareholder; (2) justice requires the veil to be pierced because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim and to shield a dominant shareholder's improprieties; and (3) an equitable result will be achieved by holding the shareholder personally liable for the acts of the business entity.

Title: Hill v. Fairfield Nursing and Rehabilitation Center, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Alabama.
Headnote: The doctrine that a corporation is a legal entity existing separate and apart from the persons composing it is a legal theory introduced for purposes of convenience and to subserve the ends of justice, and the concept cannot, therefore, be extended to a point beyond its reason and policy, and, when invoked in support of an end subversive of this policy, will be disregarded by the courts; thus, in an appropriate case and in furtherance of the ends of justice, a corporation and the individual or individuals owning all its stock and assets will be treated as identical.

Title: Timber Integrated Investments, LLC v. Welch
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the corporate form or pierce the corporate veil, and extend liability for corporate obligations beyond the confines of a corporation's separate entity, whenever necessary to prevent fraud or to achieve equity.

Title: Vitol, S.A. v. Primerose Shipping Co. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: Although decisions to pierce a corporate veil, exposing those behind the corporation to liability, must be taken reluctantly and cautiously, courts will not hesitate to take such action when justice so requires.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Legal action in Commercial Court of English High Court of Justice did not divest resulting judgment of admiralty character.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Vitol, S.A. v. Primerose Shipping Co. Ltd.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Fourth Circuit.
Headnote: At its core, the question of whether to pierce the corporate veil is a fact-intensive inquiry, because the circumstances necessarily vary according to the circumstances of each case, and every case where the issue is raised is to be regarded as sui generis to be decided in accordance with its own underlying facts; instead of a firm rule, the general principle has been that liability is imposed when doing so would achieve an equitable result.
Document Preview: MARITIME LAW - Jurisdiction. Legal action in Commercial Court of English High Court of Justice did not divest resulting judgment of admiralty character.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Serio v. Baystate Properties, LLC
Court: Court of Special Appeals of Maryland.
Headnote: Although the courts will, in a proper case, disregard the corporate entity and deal with substance rather than form, as though a corporation did not exist, shareholders generally are not held individually liable for debts or obligations of a corporation except where it is necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of LLC's veil was not warranted in absence of fraud.

Title: Flushing Plaza Associates No. 2 v. Albert
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: Equity will intervene to "pierce the corporate veil" and permit assertion of claims against individuals who control corporation in order to avoid fraud or injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing tenant's corporate veil was warranted.

Title: On Command Video Corp. v. Roti
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Illinois allows the corporate veil to be pierced, thereby exposing the corporation's owner to personal liability for the corporation's debts, if two conditions are satisfied: (1) the owner has failed to operate it as a corporation, neglecting such requisites of the corporate form as adequate capitalization, election of directors and officers, and separation of corporate from personal funds, and (2) refusing to pierce the veil would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted in suit seeking to enforce underlying statecourt default judgment.

Title: On Command Video Corp. v. Roti
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Whether adherence to the separate identities of a corporation and its owners would promote injustice, for purposes of a veil–piercing claim under Illinois law, is a vague test that asks whether there has been an abuse of limited liability, as when the owner of a party to a contract strips the party of assets so that if it breaks the contract the other party will have no remedy.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Piercing corporate veil was unwarranted in suit seeking to enforce underlying statecourt default judgment.

Title: Oskin v. Johnson

Headnote: For the purposes of piercing the corporate veil under an alter ego theory, control may be shown where the subservient entity manifests no separate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve the goals of the dominant entity; however, this theory does not apply in the absence of fraud, injustice, or contravention of public policy.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Steffner
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Tennessee.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, factors to be considered in determining whether to disregard corporate veil include not only whether entity has been used to work a fraud or injustice in contravention of public policy, but also (1) whether there was failure to collect paid in capital, (2) whether corporation was grossly undercapitalized, (3) nonissuance of stock certificates, (4) sole ownership of stock by one individual, (5) use of same office or business location, (6) employment of same employees or attorneys, (7) use of corporation as instrumentality or business conduit for individual or another corporation, (8) diversion of corporate assets by or to stockholder or other entity to detriment of creditors, or manipulation of assets and liabilities in another, (9) use of corporation as subterfuge in illegal transactions, (10) formation and use of corporation to transfer to it existing liability of another person or entity, and (11) failure to maintain arms-length relationships among related entities.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Piercing of corporate veil of limited liability company was not warranted under Tennessee law

Title: National Gear & Piston, Inc. v. Cummins Power Systems, LLC

Headnote: Under Delaware law, the legal test for determining when a corporate form should be ignored in equity cannot be reduced to a single formula that is neither over nor under-inclusive; still, a plaintiff seeking to persuade a Delaware court to disregard corporate structure faces a difficult task.
Document Preview: TORTS - Tortious Interference. Parts supplier failed to state claim against manufacturer for tortious interference with existing business relationships.

Title: Watts v. Magic 2 %2A 52 Management, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of North Dakota.
Headnote: An element of injustice, inequity or fundamental unfairness must be present before a court may properly pierce the corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Judgment. Plaintiffs who sought to pierce corporate veil post-judgment were required to move for new trial or for relief from judgment.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: First Keystone Consultants, Inc. v. Schlesinger Elec. Contractors, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts will pierce the corporate veil to hold a corporation's owners personally liable for the debts of the corporation whenever necessary to prevent fraud or achieve equity.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Officers and Directors. Contractor was entitled to money judgment against corporation and its officers on New York claims for fraudulent conveyances.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re P & J Resources, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Pikeville Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, corporate veil should be pierced on equity formulation theory only with reluctance and caution, and then only in presence of some combination of the following factors, no one of which is dispositive: (1) undercapitalization; (2) failure to observe corporate formalities; (3) nonpayment or overpayment of dividends; (4) a siphoning off of funds by dominant shareholder(s); and (5) majority shareholders having guaranteed corporate liabilities in their individual capacities.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Defendants' status as Chapter 7 debtors and size of compensatory award counseled against punitive damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re P & J Resources, Inc.
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. Kentucky, Pikeville Division.
Headnote: Under Kentucky law, regardless of whether veil-piercing is sought on equity, alter ego, or instrumentality theory, mandated factors of the equity formulation are considered in all cases, no matter what "test" is being applied.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Defendants' status as Chapter 7 debtors and size of compensatory award counseled against punitive damages.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Euro RSCG Direct Response, LLC v. Green Bullion Financial Services
Court: United States District Court, S.D. Florida.
Headnote: Under Florida law, a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil and prove alter ego liability must show both a blurring of corporate lines, such as ignoring corporate formalities or using a corporation for the stockholder's personal interest, and that the stockholder used the corporation for some illegal, fraudulent, or other unjust purpose.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Economic loss rule did not bar fraudulent inducement claim.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mbahaba v. Morgan
Court: Supreme Court of New Hampshire.
Headnote: The Supreme Court will pierce the corporate veil and assess individual liability where the owners have used the company to promote an injustice or fraud upon the plaintiff; in such a case, the Court will disregard the fiction that the corporation is independent of its stockholders and treat the stockholders as the corporation's alter egos.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Limited Liability Companies. Personal liability of LLC member was not statutorily precluded in negligence action arising out of lead exposure.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Mehl v. PortaCo, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: In Minnesota, courts will pierce the corporate veil to enforce equity against defendants who abuse the corporate form to further their own interests and protect themselves from individual liability in the process.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Discrimination. Genuine issue of material fact existed as to whether employee was treated differently than others because of her sex.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Everkrisp Vegetables Inc. v. Tobiason Potato Co., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. North Dakota, Southeastern Division.
Headnote: Under North Dakota law, element of injustice, inequity, or fundamental unfairness must be present before court may properly pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: AGRICULTURE - Products. Warranty clause that limited certified seed potato producer's liability for latent defects was not unconscionable.

Title: Rogers v. Louisville Land Co.
Court: Supreme Court of Tennessee, at Knoxville.
Headnote: In order to pierce the corporate veil, the proof must show that the separate corporate entity is a sham or a dummy or that disregarding the separate corporate entity is necessary to accomplish justice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Atelier Constantin Popescu, LLC v. JC Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lessor breached commercial lease by recklessly causing fire that destroyed building prior to lessee taking possession.

Title: Atelier Constantin Popescu, LLC v. JC Corp.
Court: Appellate Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Ordinarily the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: REAL PROPERTY - Landlord and Tenant. Lessor breached commercial lease by recklessly causing fire that destroyed building prior to lessee taking possession.

Title: Delta Development Corp. v. F. Fani Gulf Intern.
Court: Court of Appeals of Tennessee.
Headnote: When a court is convinced that a corporate entity is a sham or a dummy or that disregarding the separate corporate entity is necessary to accomplish justice, a court may pierce the corporate veil and attribute the actions of a corporation to its shareholders.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Evidence. Trial court did not abuse its discretion in finding borrower's general ledger qualified as a business record excepted from the hearsay rule.

Title: MIG Investments LLC v. Aetrex Worldwide, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, D. Delaware.
Headnote: In order to prevail on a claim for piercing the corporate veil, plaintiffs must show (1) that the corporation and its shareholders operated as a single economic entity, and (2) that an overall element of injustice or unfairness is present.
Document Preview: TORTS - Fraud. Allegations were sufficient under Delaware law to state a claim of fraud against licensee company's president.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: A.P.I., Inc. Asbestos Settlement Trust v. Home Ins. Co.
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, in determining whether to pierce corporate veil, question is whether corporation's owner abused corporate form to perpetrate injustice such that failure to pierce veil would be fundamentally unfair.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Parent corporation did not abuse corporate form by creating subsidiary to manage insurance company it had acquired.

Title: Admiral Ins. Co., Inc. v. Arrowood Indem. Co.
Court: United States District Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, "sham to perpetrate a fraud" basis for corporate disregard rests upon abuse of corporate forms as part of a basically unfair device to achieve inequitable result.

Title: Ziese & Sons Excavating, Inc. v. Boyer Const. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The courts are reluctant to disregard corporate identity; however, they may do so if it is necessary to prevent fraud or unfairness to third parties.

Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: Under Indiana law, piercing the corporate veil is rooted in principles of equity and a decision to disregard corporate entity depends upon the unique facts of each case.

Title: Ziese & Sons Excavating, Inc. v. Boyer Const. Corp.
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The authority of the courts to disregard corporate identity does not stem from the existence of a specific factual circumstance, but rather from the necessity of preventing fraud or unfairness to third parties.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether construction group was corporation's alter ego precluded summary judgment on claim to pierce the corporate veil.

Title: U.S. v. Emor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is an equitable remedy, whose exercise is subject to the sound discretion of the trial judge; the ultimate principle is one permitting its use to avoid injustice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. Emor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Treating a corporation as the alter ego of another entity is the same thing as piercing the corporate veil; it comes down to disregarding the corporation's separate existence in order to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Restitution. A nonprofit corporation was the defendant's alter ego, and thus was not entitled to restitution from the defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: U.S. v. Emor
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: A two-prong test is employed to determine whether federal common law supports piercing the corporate veil: (1) whether there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) whether an inequitable result will follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: CRIMINAL JUSTICE - Restitution. A nonprofit corporation was the defendant's alter ego, and thus was not entitled to restitution from the defendant.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Illinois law permits corporate-veil piercing when two separate prongs are met: (1) there must be such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) circumstances must be such that adherence to the fiction of separate corporate existence would sanction a fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Under Illinois law, a finding that adhering to the separate identities of the corporation and its owners would sanction a fraud or promote injustice, as required to pierce the corporate veil, requires something less than an affirmative showing of fraud, but something more than the mere prospect of an unsatisfied judgment.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Wachovia Securities, LLC v. Banco Panamericano, Inc.
Court: United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
Headnote: Illinois law endorses corporate-veil piercing to avoid unfair enrichment, to avoid permitting the creator of a corporate liability and cause of the corporation's inability to meet that liability to escape responsibility, and to avoid allowing a corporation to keep assets in a liability-free corporation while placing liabilities on an asset-free corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. District court did not clearly err in finding adherence to separate identities of corporation and insiders would sanction fraud.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Commissioner of Environmental Protection v. State Five Indus. Park, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: Courts will disregard the fiction of a separate legal entity to pierce the shield of immunity afforded by the corporate structure in a situation in which the corporate entity has been so controlled and dominated that justice requires liability to be imposed on the real actor.

Title: Commissioner of Environmental Protection v. State Five Indus. Park, Inc.
Court: Supreme Court of Connecticut.
Headnote: The law permits the incorporation of businesses for the very purpose of isolating liabilities among separate entities, and thus the corporate veil is pierced only under exceptional circumstances, for example, where the corporation is a mere shell, serving no legitimate purpose, and used primarily as an intermediary to perpetuate fraud or promote injustice.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Imposition of reverse veil piercing was unwarranted under instrumentality rule.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Best Cartage, Inc. v. Stonewall Packaging, LLC
Court: Court of Appeals of North Carolina.
Headnote: Piercing the corporate veil is a drastic remedy and should be invoked only in an extreme case where necessary to serve the ends of justice.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Guifu Li v. A Perfect Day Franchise, Inc
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California, San Jose Division.
Headnote: While there is no specific litmus test for determining whether an individual is an alter ego of a corporate entity, California imposes two general requirements: (1) that there be such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist; and (2) that if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, an inequitable result will follow.

Title: Nippert v. Jackson
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: To pierce the corporate veil under Tennessee law, a court must be convinced that the separate corporate entity is a sham or a dummy or that disregarding the separate corporate entity is necessary to accomplish justice.

Title: CBR Event Decorators, Inc. v. Gates

Headnote: Courts are reluctant to disregard corporate identity and do so only where the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil can establish that the corporate form has been misused and the result of that misuse is fraud or injustice.

Title: CBR Event Decorators, Inc. v. Gates
Court: Court of Appeals of Indiana.
Headnote: The fraud or injustice alleged by a party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must be caused by, or result from, misuse of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Lack of causal connection between misuse of corporate form and alleged fraud or injustice precluded shareholder liability.

Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, courts will disregard the corporate form, or pierce the corporate veil, to hold a corporation's owners liable for the debts of the corporation whenever necessary to prevent an injustice or to achieve equity.

Title: In re Adler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, E.D. New York.
Headnote: Under New York law, plaintiff seeking to pierce the corporate veil may be considered "injured" by defendant's actions when company is rendered unable to pay claims pending against it by third parties because of defendant's domination of company's business.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor's domination of corporations and use of those corporations to commit wrong permitted piercing corporate veil.

Title: Inter-Tel Technologies, Inc. v. Linn Station Properties, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Kentucky.
Headnote: Though the injustice alleged by a creditor seeking to pierce a corporate veil must be something beyond the mere inability to collect a debt, actual fraud is not required in order to pierce a corporate veil, overruling White v. Winchester Land Development Corp., 584 S.W.2d 56. KRS 271B.6–220(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual fraud not required in order to pierce veil of tenant which was retail branch for parent and grandparent corporations.

Title: Inter-Tel Technologies, Inc. v. Linn Station Properties, LLC
Court: Supreme Court of Kentucky.
Headnote: When assessing the second element of piercing a corporate veil, i.e., circumstances under which continued recognition of the corporation would sanction fraud or promote injustice, court should state specifically the fraud or injustice that would be sanctioned if the court declined to pierce the corporate veil. KRS 271B.6–220(2).
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Actual fraud not required in order to pierce veil of tenant which was retail branch for parent and grandparent corporations.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Fernbach, LLC v. Calleo
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The corporate veil will be pierced to achieve equity, even absent fraud, when a corporation has been so dominated by an individual or another corporation and its separate entity so ignored that it primarily transacts the dominator's business instead of its own and can be called the other's alter ego.

Title: Martin v. Freeman
Court: Colorado Court of Appeals, Div. VII.
Headnote: The second prong of the veil-piercing test is whether justice requires recognizing the substance of the relationship between the corporation and the person or entity sought to be held liable over the form because the corporate fiction was used to perpetrate a fraud or defeat a rightful claim.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. LLC's sale of its sole asset was an attempt to defeat creditor's rightful claim for purposes of piercing corporate veil.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Newcrete Products v. City of Wilkes-Barre
Court: Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania.
Headnote: Where a corporation operates as a mere facade for the operations of a dominant shareholder, the dominating shareholder may be held liable for the corporation's inequitable conduct perpetrated through the use of the corporate form's protections.

Title: Christopher v. Sinyard
Court: Court of Appeals of Georgia.
Headnote: The concept of "piercing the corporate veil" is applied in Georgia to remedy injustices which arise where a party has overextended his privilege in the use of a corporate entity in order to defeat justice, perpetrate fraud or to evade contractual or tort responsibility.

Title: Heisz v. Galt Industries, Inc.

Title: East Hampton Union Free School Dist. v. Sandpebble Builders, Inc.

Title: Plese-Graham, LLC v. Loshbaugh
Court: Court of Appeals of Washington, Division 3.
Headnote: To disregard corporate entity and assess liability against shareholders in corporation under duty owed theory of corporate disregard, the wrongful corporate activities, as required for element that disregard is necessary to prevent unjustified loss to the injured party, activities must actually harm the party seeking relief; intentional misconduct must be the cause of the harm that is avoided by disregard.

Title: In re Thompson
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, S.D. Ohio, Eastern Division.
Headnote: Under Ohio law, the "veil" of a corporation may be "pierced" and individual shareholders held liable for corporate misdeeds when it would be unjust to allow the shareholders to hide behind the fiction of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Business Relationships. Creditor of company was not entitled to pierce corporate veil to hold company's owners liable for debt.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Oliver v. Black Knight Asset Management, LLC
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Under District of Columbia law, to pierce the corporate veil court must determine: (1) whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that separate personalities of a corporation and an individual no longer exist, and (2) if acts are treated as those of the corporation alone, whether an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Terminated employee stated ERISA claim against her employer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Pope v. Heritage Communities, Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of South Carolina.
Headnote: South Carolina employs a two prong test for piercing the corporate veil; the first prong analyzes the shareholder's relationship to the corporation by evaluating eight factors, and the second prong requires the plaintiff to demonstrate that fundamental unfairness would result from recognition of the corporate entity.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jury. Property development companies were not prejudiced by trial court's misstatement of law on negligence in instructing jury.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Hydroxycut Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Both California and Delaware law require some form of misconduct or injustice to justify piercing the corporate veil.

Title: In re Hydroxycut Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation
Court: United States District Court, S.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, mere difficulty in enforcing a judgment or collecting a debt does not satisfy the requirement for misconduct or injustice necessary to pierce corporate veil.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Subsidiary was an agent of its parent company, for purposes of imputing its minimum contacts with state to parent.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: TAC-Critical Systems, Inc. v. Integrated Facility Systems, Inc.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: Federal common-law test for piercing the corporate veil proceeds in two steps, asking (1) whether there is such unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the corporation and the individual no longer exist, and (2) whether an inequitable result follow if the acts are treated as those of the corporation alone.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Whether corporate veil could be pierced to hold contractor's principal individually liable presented triable fact issues.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Matthews
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Georgia, Atlanta Division.
Headnote: Under Florida law, those who utilize laws of Florida in order to do business in corporate form have every right to rely on rules of law which protect them against personal liability, unless it is shown that corporation was formed or used for some illegal, fraudulent or other unjust purposes which justifies piercing corporate veil.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Debtor Protections. Automatic stay applied to attempts to collect attorney fees incurred postpetition.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Harrelson v. Seung Heun Lee
Court: United States District Court, D. Massachusetts.
Headnote: Under Massachusetts law, the corporate veil will be pierced only to defeat fraud or to remedy injustice.
Document Preview: LITIGATION - Jurisdiction. Exercise of personal jurisdiction over nonresident defendant, based on contacts of his alter ego corporations, was warranted.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Doe v. U.S.
Court: United States District Court, District of Columbia.
Headnote: The ultimate principle of piercing the corporate veil under District of Columbia law is one permitting its use to avoid injustice.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Workers' Compensation. Scientist's tort claims arising from exposure to mad-cow disease were barred by District of Columbia's Workers' Compensation Act.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: ABN AMRO Bank, N.V. v. MBIA Inc.
Court: Court of Appeals of New York.
Headnote: The party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the owners, through their domination, abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Industry Regulation. Administrative approval of insurer's restructuring did not bar challenge to restructuring as fraudulent transaction.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: American Nat. Property and Cas. Co. v. Campbell Ins., Inc.
Court: United States District Court, M.D. Tennessee, Nashville Division.
Headnote: Under Tennessee law, to pierce the corporate veil, a court must be convinced that the separate corporate entity is a sham or a dummy or that disregarding the separate corporate entity is necessary to accomplish justice.
Document Preview: INSURANCE - Agents and Brokers. Stockholder who transferred her interest in insurance agency before she began competing against insurer did not breach agency contract.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Martin v. Spring Break 83 Production, LLC
Court: United States District Court, E.D. Louisiana.
Headnote: Under Louisiana law, at least one of four general circumstances must be satisfied before a court will pierce the corporate veil: (1) a court will pierce the corporate veil if a third party is a victim of fraud, breach of professional duty, negligence, or another wrongful act by the individual member of the limited liability company (LLC); (2) a court will pierce the corporate veil if the members of the LLC use the corporate form to defeat public convenience, justify wrong, protect fraud, or defend crime; (3) a court will pierce the corporate veil if adherence to the corporate form would clearly result in inequity; and (4) a court will pierce the corporate veil if it finds evidence of misuse of corporate privilege.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Hours and Wages. Nonsignatory film producer and its individual employees were not employers under the FLSA.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Hottenstein v. City of Seal Isle City
Court: United States District Court, D. New Jersey.
Headnote: Under New Jersey law, a corporation is a separate entity from its shareholders, and that a primary reason for incorporation is the insulation of shareholders from the liabilities of the corporate enterprise; accordingly, except in cases of fraud, injustice, or the like, courts will not pierce a corporate veil.
Document Preview: TORTS - Dram Shop. Negligence claims against bars were barred by the New Jersey Dram Shop Act's exclusive remedy provision.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Walsh v. Kindred Healthcare
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, a corporate identity may be disregarded where an abuse of the corporate privilege justifies holding the equitable ownership of a corporation liable for the actions of the corporation.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Skilled nursing facility (SNF) residents' allegations were sufficient to invoke alter ego doctrine for class action claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Walsh v. Kindred Healthcare
Court: United States District Court, N.D. California.
Headnote: Under California law, to invoke the alter ego doctrine, plaintiffs must allege: (1) there is such a unity of interest and ownership that the separate personalities of the two corporations no longer exist, and (2) if the acts are treated as those of only one of the corporations, an inequitable result will follow.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Parent and Subsidiary. Skilled nursing facility (SNF) residents' allegations were sufficient to invoke alter ego doctrine for class action claims.

Title: DeRosa v. Accredited Home Lenders, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: Except in cases of fraud, injustice, or the like, courts will not pierce a corporate veil.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. In determining whether parent and affiliated companies may be held liable under state WARN Act, courts must apply 5-factor test.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: DeRosa v. Accredited Home Lenders, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: The purpose of the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is to prevent an independent corporation from being used to defeat the ends of justice, to perpetrate fraud, to accomplish a crime, or otherwise to evade the law.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Layoffs. In determining whether parent and affiliated companies may be held liable under state WARN Act, courts must apply 5-factor test.

Title: Michnovez v. Blair, LLC
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Under New Hampshire law, courts do not hesitate to disregard fiction of corporation when circumstances would lead to an inequitable result.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Under New Hampshire law, corporation was not liable for the negligence of its sister corporation.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, "sham to perpetuate injustice" or "sham to perpetrate a fraud" theory of piercing the corporate veil is an equitable doctrine, and Texas courts take a flexible fact-specific approach focusing on equity.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Arnette
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, N.D. Texas, Dallas Division.
Headnote: Under Texas law, focus of the analysis under "sham to perpetuate injustice" or "sham to perpetrate a fraud" theory of piercing the corporate veil is on some inequitable result for the claimant, because of abuses of the corporate form.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Discharge. Debtor's personal liability for fraud committed against investor by his companies fell within fraud discharge exception.

Title: Peery v. United Capital Corp.
Court: Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Second Department, New York.
Headnote: The party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must establish that the controlling corporation or individuals abused the privilege of doing business in the corporate form to perpetrate a wrong or injustice against that party such that a court in equity will intervene.

Title: Tealwood Properties, L.L.C. v. Succession of Graves
Court: Court of Appeal of Louisiana, Second Circuit.
Headnote: "Veil-piercing" with respect to a corporation is a flexible doctrine that can be used in any situation in which the separate personality of the corporation appears to be blocking a just result.

Title: Leek v. Cooper

Headnote: The corporate form will be disregarded only in narrowly defined circumstances and only when the ends of justice so require.

Title: Leek v. Cooper
Court: Court of Appeal, Third District, California.
Headnote: Before a corporation's obligations can be recognized as those of a particular person, the requisite unity of interest and inequitable result must be shown.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Employer's Liability. Corporation's sole shareholder was not employees' employer for purposes of FEHA discrimination claims.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: In re Fields
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, factors that would support a finding of identity between individual principal and corporation, so as to warrant piercing the corporate veil, include (1) insufficient capitalization, (2) failure to observe corporate formalities, (3) nonpayment of dividends, (4) insolvency of debtor corporation, and (5) siphoning of corporation as a mere facade for individual dealings; in addition, there must be an element of injustice or a fundamental unfairness that would result from honoring the nominal separateness of the corporation.
Document Preview: BANKRUPTCY - Claims. Debtor, as borrower's principal, was not directly liable for obligation to lender.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Sean Wood, L.L.C. v. Hegarty Group, Inc.
Court: Superior Court of New Jersey, Appellate Division.
Headnote: The doctrine of piercing the corporate veil is employed when fraud or injustice has been perpetrated.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Agent of seller of industrial equipment could be personally liable for failure to pay transporter for delivering equipment to buyer.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Louisburg Bldg. & Development Co., L.L.C. v. Albright
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: A corporate entity may also be disregarded upon a general showing that the interests of justice require it; this theory for disregarding the corporate entity does not require a showing that the corporation itself was used to perpetrate the injustice, but there must at least be some injustice or inequity that would result from maintaining the legal fiction of separate entities.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic-loss doctrine precluded homeowners' fraud-in-the-inducement claim against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Louisburg Bldg. & Development Co., L.L.C. v. Albright
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: Even under the interests-of-justice theory for disregarding a corporate entity, there must be some showing that it would be inequitable or unjust to uphold the legal fiction of separate entities; merely showing that some kind of injustice occurred is not sufficient.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic-loss doctrine precluded homeowners' fraud-in-the-inducement claim against contractor.

Key Number: 101 CORPORATIONS AND BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS > 101II Disregarding Corporate Entity;  Piercing Corporate Veil > 101k1035 Reasons and Justifications > 101k1037 Justice and equity in general >
Title: Louisburg Bldg. & Development Co., L.L.C. v. Albright
Court: Court of Appeals of Kansas.
Headnote: A fraud or injustice committed by a corporation ordinarily will be remedied by the penalties that the law assesses against that corporation as a remedy; it is the corporation's inability or unwillingness to comply with those remedies that prompts disregarding the corporate entity.
Document Preview: COMMERCIAL LAW - Contracts. Economic-loss doctrine precluded homeowners' fraud-in-the-inducement claim against contractor.

Title: Antaeus Enterprises, Inc. v. Davidson
Court: United States District Court, D. New Hampshire.
Headnote: Ordinarily, corporate owners are not liable for a corporation's debts under New Hampshire law, barring an agreement to the contrary; courts will pierce the corporate veil and assess individual liability, however, where the corporate identity has been used to promote an injustice or fraud.
Document Preview: BUSINESS ORGANIZATIONS - Piercing Corporate Veil. Fact issue precluded summary judgment in action brought by judgment creditors of LLC, seeking to pierce LLC's corporate veil.

Title: In re Rood

Headnote: Under Maryland law, corporate shareholders generally are not held individually liable for debts or obligations of a corporation except where it is necessary to prevent fraud or enforce a paramount equity.

Title: In re Pierron

Headnote: Under Tennessee law, fraud or similar injustice must be demonstrated in order to pierce the corporate veil; veil-piercing does not require a showing of actual fraud.

Title: Wilson v. Thorn Energy, LLC
Court: United States District Court, S.D. New York.
Headnote: Under Delaware law, a plaintiff seeking to hold owners of a corporation liable for the corporation's debts faces a difficult task; corporate veil may be pierced only in the interest of justice, when such matters as fraud, contravention of law or contract, or public wrong are involved.

Title: Wilson v. Thorn Energy, LLC

Headnote: To resolve alter-ego piercing claim under Delaware law, court asks: (1) whether the entities in question operated as a single economic entity, and (2) whether there was an overall element of injustice or unfairness.

Title: In re Wheeler
Court: United States Bankruptcy Court, D. Idaho.
Headnote: Under Idaho law, courts may disregard corporate form if two requirements are met: (1) there must be unity of interest and ownership such that separate personalities of corporation and individual no longer exist; and (2) failure to treat acts of corporation as those of individual must lead to inequitable result or sanction a fraud or promote injustice.

Title: Milestone Shipping, S.A. v. Estech Trading LLC

Title: Thorkelson v. Publishing House of Evangelical Lutheran Church in America

Title: Thorkelson v. Publishing House of Evangelical Lutheran Church in America
Court: United States District Court, D. Minnesota.
Headnote: Under Minnesota law, factors considered significant in determination of whether one corporation can be held liable for another entity's wrongdoing include insufficient capitalization for purposes of corporate undertaking, failure to observe corporate formalities, nonpayment of dividends, insolvency of debtor corporation at time of transaction in question, siphoning of funds by dominant shareholder, nonfunctioning of other officers and directors, absence of corporate records, and existence of corporation as merely facade for individual dealings; next, court must consider whether there is showing of injustice or fundamental unfairness.
Document Preview: LABOR AND EMPLOYMENT - Benefit Plans. Single employer defined benefit pension plan was church plan exempt from Employee Retirement Income Security Act.

Headnote: In applying alter ego doctrine, under Minnesota law, a court is to analyze "reality" of corporate functions and to find injustice or fundamental unfairness.

Title: Shaoxing County Huayue Import & Export v. Bhaumik
Court: Court of Appeal, Second District, Division 5, California.
Headnote: There are two general requirements for the court to consider when determining whether to pierce the corporate veil; first, there must be such a unity of interest and ownership between the corporation and its equitable owner that the separate personalities of the corporation and the shareholder do not in reality exist, and second, there must be an inequitable result if the acts in question are treated as those of the corporation alone.

Title: In re Kummerfeld

Title: Greenspan v. LADT, LLC
